Our Daily Prayer The Authority of Jesus Challenged Today's Gospel is from Matthew 22:15-21 The Pharisees went off and plotted how they might entrap Jesus in speech. They sent their disciples to him, with the Herodians, saying, "Teacher, we know that you are a truthful man and that you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. And you are not concerned with anyone's opinion, for you do not regard a person's status. Tell us, then, what is your opinion: Is it lawful to pay the census tax to Caesar or not?" Knowing their malice, Jesus said, "Why are you testing me, you hypocrites? Show me the coin that pays the census tax." Then they handed him the Roman coin. He said to them, "Whose image is this and whose inscription?" They replied, "Caesar's." At that he said to them, "Then repay to Caesar what belongs to Caesar and to God what belongs to God." In Matthew 22:15-21, the Pharisees and Herodians attempt to trap Jesus with a question about paying taxes to Caesar. They ask him, "Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?" (Matthew 22:17) Jesus knows their intent, and he asks them to show him a coin. When they do, he asks them, "Whose image and inscription is this?" (Matthew 22:20) They reply, "Caesar's." (Matthew 22:21) Jesus then tells them, "Render therefore to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's." (Matthew 22:21) This passage is often interpreted as a statement about the separation of church and state. However, it is important to note that Jesus is not saying that we should not pay taxes. In fact, he is saying that we should pay our taxes because they are due to Caesar or the state. What Jesus is saying is that there are two different authorities in the world: the authority of the state and the authority of God. The state is responsible for maintaining order and providing for the common good. God is responsible for our spiritual well-being. We are obligated to obey both authorities. We must pay our taxes and obey the laws of the land. However, we must also obey God's laws. If there is a conflict between the laws of the state and the laws of God, we must obey God. This passage is a reminder that we are citizens of two kingdoms: the kingdom of this world and the kingdom of God. We have obligations to both kingdoms, but our ultimate allegiance is to God. Complete Gospel Reflection for today: https://mycatholic.life/books/catholic-daily-reflections-series-two/ordinary-time-week-18-34-series-two/twenty-ninth-week-in-ordinary-time/#Sun-A:=:https://mycatholic.life/books/catholic-daily-reflections-series-two/ordinary-time-week-18-34-series-two/twenty-ninth-week-in-ordinary-time/

Dear 100-Level Student ​ ​ ​ You see, the motivation to read can be very spontaneous. It could be an effect of a short moment of self-reflectionor anything at all. ​ But then, that motivation needs to be met with some other factors, so your decision could be speedy. These factors are catalysts. They help speed up your decision process. ​ ​ For me, some of these factors include: ​ ✔ A filled stomach, is very important. ​ ✔ A clear head. ​ ✔ A clean environment. ​ ​ ​ Reading actually is an exercise, and it requires a reasonable amount of energy. Food gives you that energy (if you can do away with junk, please do). Lol, let me personalise it, food gives me the energy I need to read. ​ ​ ​ Have you noticed what happens when you try to read on an empty stomach? You keep reading a particular line over and over again until whatever you're reading loses its meaning. Yes, I'm talking from experience. As of that moment, the energy you need to comprehend what you're reading is lacking. You need to refill. ​ ​ ​ A clear head gives room for more information to be received, and stored. If you're like me, the mere thought of having some dirty clothes to wash can affect my reading time or pattern. Sometimes, it goes like this; ​ ​ ​ "Soil texture is the degree of… chai! The dress I wore yesterday with the ones in that bucket makes it six dirty clothes I have to wash. Omo! I don't have detergent again, and I don't have any cash on me. Eh! Fareedah owes me 1k, let me go and ask her before she goes to Dama". ​ ​ ​ And then in Fareedah's room, there will be something to talk about. Goodbye soil texture. ​ ​ ​ ​ Phew! ​ ​ Notice how it all started with a simple thought? That's how a disturbed mind can alter your reading process. Yours might be different. It could be the need to cook, a troubling issue at home, an unresolved conflict, or what have you. A cluttered mind is a stressed mind, and a stressed mind is a closed mind. ​ ​ ​ Still using myself as a case study on the importance of a clean environment. A clean environment boosts my creativity. I write better when my environment is clean, I read better, I sleep better. ​ ​ Your bedroom, kitchen, bathroom, and other areas are your environment. These parts of where you live are like your mind on display. Remember what happens to a cluttered mind? Yes. ​ ​ You may have noticed how sluggish you are in a dirty environment. The same way to count your steps, and block your nostrils in disgust when you walk past an area littered with filth is the same way your brain acts when it senses that your environment is dirty. Every action you take is as a result of the signals your brain sends to you. There is always a pattern. ​ ​ How do you read when you can't even breathe? ​ ​ Perhaps you can read but how do you assimilate when your brain is struggling with what to focus on? ​ ​ ⭕What You Can Do This Weekend To Help Yourself⭕ ​ ​ ​ ✔ Save yourself some weekday stress. Cook. If you can, make a stew that will last for a few days into the week. That way you're not always worried about what to eat or cook when you're back from class. That moment of thought is another level of stress on its own, you don't need it. That way, you also get time to rest after a stressful day. You need all the rest you can get. ​ ​ ​ ​ ✔ About a clear head. You need to declutter to the tiniest detail. Wash your plates, do your laundry, pick your clothes for the following week, fetch water, resolve your conflicts, dwell on the situations you have control over, and set yourself up for a great mood (music works for me). Basically, try to free your mind, and create space in your head for assimilation. ​ ​ ​ ​ ✔ A clean environment. This weekend just do what you always do, general sanitation. Wipe the walls and ceiling, make your bed, clear your reading table, rearrange your clothes, clean your shoe racks, mop your floor, and clean your kitchen and bathroom. If you have, use air freshener in moderation. Do everything to make your surroundings clean, and healthy, and enable you to read. ​ ​ ​ Don't underestimate the importance of doing these little things. They might seem little and insignificant but they make up the big issues. ​ ​ ​ It becomes easier for you to read for an impromptu test when you have no worries about what to eat, cooking, rumpled clothes on your bed or chairs to fold, meruwa to supply water e.t.c. ​ ​ ​ No, these things, however simple they sound, aren't always exciting to do. I know it's not easy, especially the financial aspect. The state of the country's economy is worrisome, however, there are times when you're financially buoyant. Take care of yourself. ​ ​ A happy stomach, a ready brain. ​ A cleared mind, a time to assimilate. ​ A clean environment is the motivation you need to start. ​ In all, a clever way to guard your state of mind, stay healthy, and be ready for success. I pray that God makes it easy for you to get the resources you need to excel. ​ Enjoy your weekend. ​ Aisha (truncated)

So we have to understand our life, the life that we lead, the life that has become meaningless, the life that is full of travail, sorrow, conflict, competition, dishonesty. And in learning about that we shall also learn what love is. And in learning what love is we shall learn also what death is, because life is all that - death, love and everyday living. And to merely concentrate on everyday living, that is, bread and butter, position, more things and so on, so on, so on, and neglect the rest of it, which is what the world is doing, therefore it is imbalance, therefore it is contradictory, and therefore it is mischievous. So we have to learn about the whole thing - death, love and daily living.

First we must see clearly for ourself what our daily living is. What is our living? What is the thing that we call living? Do we live, or do we tolerate living? Do we live according to an idea, according to a conclusion based on a belief, a dogma, a memory? Because the mind is always concerned with remembering, imagining, contriving. I do not know if... Please we are moving together. If you have observed your mind you will see imagination plays a tremendous part, remembering and calculating, contriving. On that is based our life, the daily existence, the images which we have built about each other in our relationship with each other. And these images have their relationship and so we lose direct relationship. If I have an image about you because I have lived with you for ten years, or five days, and you have your image about me because you have lived with me for ten days or five years, our relationship is essentially based on that image. The images have relationship, not you and I, there is no direct response between each other. And therefore relationship comes to an end. I don't know if you... 𝐂𝐌𝐎𝐑 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐏𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞𝐫 𝐁𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐨𝐧 “𝑻𝒆𝒍𝒍 𝒎𝒆 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝑰 𝒇𝒐𝒓𝒈𝒆𝒕, 𝒕𝒆𝒂𝒄𝒉 𝒎𝒆 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝑰 𝒎𝒂𝒚 𝒓𝒆𝒎𝒆𝒎𝒃𝒆𝒓, 𝒊𝒏𝒗𝒐𝒍𝒗𝒆 𝒎𝒆 𝒂𝒏𝒅 𝑰 𝒍𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒏.” — 𝑩𝒆𝒏𝒋𝒂𝒎𝒊𝒏 𝑭𝒓𝒂𝒏𝒌𝒍𝒊𝒏 BGen Benjamin De Leon Hao PA, Commander of the Civil-Military Operations Regiment (CMOR) of the Philippine Army, visited the 3rd CMO Battalion at Camp Martin Jaen Sr, Brgy Nabitasan, Leganes, Iloilo, on October 17, 2023, Tuesday. Bgen Hao was pleasantly welcomed by the officers and enlisted personnel of 3CMOBn, headed by Ltc Luisita G Clavecillas II, Commanding Officer. The visit run through the conduct of Brain-talk @ 3CMOBn with a Theme: ”Kaupod sa Kalinong kag Kauswagan (Partners for Peace and Progress)”, virtual teleconferencing forum highlighted several topics relative to Integration of CMOBns to CMOR, PA by BGen Hao; End Local Communist Armed Conflict (ELCAC) Role in Influencing Key Leaders to be Insurgency-Resilient by Prosecutor Flosemer Chris Gonzales, Spokesperson Regional Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict (RTF-ELCAC); Role of Student in Nation Building by Prof Ruben Magan Gamala, Faculty, University of the Philippines Visayas; Child Exploitation involving Armed Conflict by Prof John D Catuna, PhD, Associate Professor, Iloilo State University of Fisheries Science and Technology; and Government Programs/Efforts to Protect the Youth Against Communist Terrorist Groups (CTGs) Decisive Recruitment by Ms Gabriel H Delos Reyes, Research Specialist, National Intelligence Coordinating Agency (NICA-6). BGen Hao facilitated the ceremonial wearing of Tan Beret and Donning of CMOR patch, that marks the absorption of 3CMOBn from 3ID to CMOR, PA. Awards were also given to the deserving personnel in their utmost dedication rendered in the unit’s mission accomplishment. BGen Hao expressed his organizational development plan to capacitate the CMOBns aligned to its mission using the three Pillars of CMO; Public Affairs (PA), Civil Affairs (CA), and Psychological Operations (Psyops). Moreover, he emphasized that the 3CMOBn troopers will be more professional in the field of CMO and encouraged personnel to undergo certification programs offered by CMO School, CMOR, PA and become CMO Illegible. The Regiment Commander lauded the unit’s efforts and initiatives in promoting peace and development in Western and Central Visayas. The 3CMOBn will continuously support and advocate social responsibility and rights of individuals in pursuing the essence of progressive society. The Peacemaker troopers will offer their best with dedication and hard work for their commitment and duty, not only in the areas of operation but for the nation as a whole. #WithOurStakeholders,WeBridgeHope,WeBringPeaceUnitedasOne #ServingthePeopleSecuringtheLand #YourPhilippineArmy #PeacemakerInTheVisayas #101.0K3FMKaupodsaKalinongkagKauswagan #3IDLovedbythePeople #3IDFearedbytheEnemy #PhilippineArmySpearheadTroopers #SundaloSalamatsaSerbisyo #3rdCmobnPhilArmy #AFP@87 #MAPAYAPA #MATATAG #MAUNLAD #EO70 Philippine Army Spearhead Troopers Rbs Cmo Spearhead 94th Infantry Battalion, 3ID, PA 79th Infantry "Masaligan" Battalion, 3ID, PA Wo Ai Ne 𝟯𝟬𝟭𝗦𝗧 𝗜𝗡𝗙𝗔𝗡𝗧𝗥𝗬 "𝗕𝗔𝗬𝗔𝗡𝗜𝗛𝗔𝗡" 𝗕𝗥𝗜𝗚𝗔𝗗𝗘

Set was always stressful. Especially on a Gymkhana shoot. We set a high bar, that we kept raising. Subsequently, tensions raised, too. I wish I could say we always saw eye to eye, and never had friction, but that’s not real life. And, if I’m being honest with myself, it’s not how Ken wanted it. This photo was taken in San Fransisco, on production for Gymkhana FIVE. It had been seven years since we first met, and three years into working together full time. It was around this era that I realized that my willingness to disagree, and stand strong for my opinions, is why he trusted me. You see, Ken was that once-in-a-generation, creative genius in our space (Action Sports & Motorsports). He just saw it, and had the organization and acumen to make it reality. This meant that many didn’t dare oppose him. Blame my mom, the Queens kid in me, or that conflict is my love language, but I never hesitated to push back. And not only did he accept it, he respected it (mostly). That said, he never let me win easy. He taught me to prove my point, and own my ideas, but also to choose the best idea even if it wasn’t mine. He did this by example. And in the end, no matter the creative skirmish we’d have, he’d have a smile on his face moments later. It was just part of our relationship. My only regret is that sometimes I didn’t accept those smiles fast enough. 

Fucking miss you. 
(KB Stories 13/43) #kb43stories @kblock43

Using his donkey, Almond, and a cart, Jameel fills water tanks for his neighbors, free of charge. Despite the danger posed by missile attacks, he is determined to help those in need.⁠
.⁠
Jameel's efforts have been greatly appreciated by his community, who offer food for Almond as a token of gratitude. He believes it is his duty to assist others, stating that as long as people are in need, he will continue his relief efforts.⁠
.⁠
🔗Tap the link in our bio for more.⁠
.⁠
 #Palestine #Israel #Israel_Gaza_War⁠
.⁠
📝 Mohammed R Mhawesh for Al Jazeera English⁠
📸 Ahmed Zakot, @Reuters

VVD-lijsttreker Dilan Yeşilgöz haalt hard uit naar de ruim 300 ambtenaren die oproepen om de onvoorwaardelijke steun aan Israël in te trekken.

De groep rijksambtenaren kwam gisteren in verzet tegen het kabinet van Rutte, vanwege de omgang met het conflict tussen Israël en Gaza. De ambtenaren riepen in een brief op om Israël een 'halt toe te roepen' en onschuldige burgers te beschermen.

‘Als ambtenaar kun je privé een mening hebben, die kun je ook met mij bespreken maar uiteindelijk bepaalt de politieke leiding de lijn, niet andersom’, zegt minister van Justitie Yeşilgöz. 
—
RTLnieuws

Biden has spent the last week in frenzied diplomacy to prevent the Israel-Hamas war from spiraling into a broader conflict. But if those efforts fail, the US response may depend on the blunt force of its military.⁣
⁣
The Pentagon has moved the aircraft carrier Gerald R. Ford and its battle group into the eastern Mediterranean and deployed the Dwight D. Eisenhower carrier strike group. Each bristles with F/A-18 Super Hornet fighter jets and other advanced aircraft. ⁣
⁣
In addition, 2,000 Marines have been put on heightened alert for potential mobilization. Head to the link in bio to read more.⁣
⁣

The president of a Detroit synagogue was found stabbed to death outside her home Saturday, police and the synagogue said.

The police did not have any information on a possible motive behind the killing, which is being investigated as a homicide.

Her death comes as law enforcement agencies across the country are warning of increased anti-Semitic threats in light of the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict.

പാർഥിപൻ das brothersനേ കൊന്ന് ഒരു ഗോടൗൺ കത്തിച്ചതിനാണ് വിക്രം അയാളെ recruit ചെയ്തത് എന്ന് കരുതുന്നവർ ഉറപ്പായും ഒന്നുകൂടി കണ്ടുനോക്കണം ആ രംഗം കൃത്യമായി.

"ശബ്ദം കേട്ടിട്ട് എന്നെ മനസിലായില്ലേ"

 എന്ന് വിക്രം ചോദിക്കുമ്പോൾ അതുവരെ curious ആയിരുന്ന വിജയുടെ മുഖത്ത് ഒരു relief വരുന്നത് clear ആണ്. അതായത് already പാർഥി ആണ് leo എന്ന് അറിയാവുന്ന ഒരാൾ ആണ് വിക്രം 🙌🏻

കുറേകൂടി depthൽ പറഞ്ഞാൽ പലതവണ സ്വന്തം death fake ചെയ്ത് മറ്റൊരു identity സ്വീകരിച്ചിട്ടുള്ള വിക്രമിന്റെ അതേ രീതിയിൽ തന്നെയാണ് leo identity hide ചെയ്ത് ജീവിക്കുന്നത്. വിക്രമിനും ലിയൊക്കും കഴിഞ്ഞ കാലത്തിൽ തന്നെ പരിചയം ഉണ്ട് എന്നത് സ്പഷ്ടമാണ് 💯

Flashbackൽ ലിയോയുടെ സിസ്റ്ററിനെ harold കൊല്ലുന്നതും ലിയൊക്കെ വെടിയേൽക്കുന്നതും ഉൾപെടെ ഉള്ള flashback portions സത്യം ആണെങ്കിൽ കൂടി അകത്തു ബലി കൊടുക്കാനുള്ള ശ്രമവും അതിനെ തുടർന്നുണ്ടായതാണ് conflict എന്നതും ഹൃദയരാജ് ഡിസൂസ (Mansoor ali khan) കാണാത്ത കാര്യങ്ങളാണ്. പിന്നെ അതെങ്ങനെ അയാൾ അറിഞ്ഞു. അതറിയാനുള്ള ഒരവസരം നേരിട്ട് ഉണ്ടാവാത്ത പക്ഷം അതയാൾ പറയുന്ന ഒരു കള്ളം ആവാനുള്ള സാധ്യതകളേറെയാണ് 🚫

പിന്നെ leo വിക്രമിന്റെ കൂടെ എന്തിന് പോണം എന്ന ചോദ്യത്തിനുള്ള ഉത്തരവും അതിൽ തന്നെയുണ്ട്.
"Das brothersനേ നശിപ്പിച്ചത് കൊണ്ട് മാത്രം നിന്റെ പ്രശ്നങ്ങൾ തീരുമെന്ന് കരുതുന്നുണ്ടോ?"
എന്ന വിക്രമിന്റെ ചോദ്യത്തിലുണ്ട് പാർഥിപനേ തേടിവരുന്ന ശത്രുകൾ പൂർണമായി അവസാനിച്ചിട്ടില്ല എന്നതിനുള്ള സൂചന!!😌💥

The Foreign Ministries of Turkey, Egypt, and the World Health Organization (WHO) condemned the Israeli attack on Al-Ahli Arab Baptist Hospital in Gaza, calling it a violation of international humanitarian law.

The UN Secretary-General and Saudi Arabia also condemned this attack, denouncing Israel's actions that killed at least 500 people, mostly civilians. The hospital was described as a shelter for people injured and displaced by previous attacks. All sides emphasized the need to protect civilians and abide by international humanitarian law in the conflict.

Source : VOA indonesia

A Bengaluru cop stopped the ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ chant during the Pakistan-Australia ICC World Cup match at M Chinnaswamy Stadium on Friday. Following this, a video of the incident is circulating on social media.

In the video, the cop can be heard asking the Pakistan fan not to raise the ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ slogan during the match. He said, “Bharat Mata ki Jai is allowed but not Pakistan Zindabad.”

However, when the Pakistan fan asked the cop to say the same on camera, he remained silent.

Reactions of netizens on ‘Pakistan Zindabad’ chant
On social media, the video has not only gone viral but also triggered reactions. Some supported the Pakistani fan, while others appreciated the cop’s action.

One of them wrote, “This is my problem. They are fans of Pakistan allowed by us with a visa. As long as they aren’t breaking any law, why should it concern who they cheer? The police officer seems worried more than concerned and isn’t sure why he had to ask the fan to stop cheering for his team. We all need to know where to draw our line when it comes to guests. If we don’t want them, let’s not give them visas. But we have to uphold the dignity of a sport.”

Another user wrote, “To avoid conflict and riots, you know how our crowd is, tomorrow they get violent and take law in their hands, to prevent that they are saying not to chant pakistan zindabad.”
.
#Bengaluru #ICCWorldCup2023

When Rathbone deBuys posts TikTok videos critiquing Israel in its conflict with Hamas, he turns to common strategies to avoid being detected and deleted by the social media giant.

In the subtitles of his videos, he uses terrier and violin emojis instead of the words “terrorist” and “violence.” At the bottom of his videos — which have collectively received millions of likes — he adds a disclaimer, saying the post is for “educational” purposes only. 

Changing the captions may make it less likely that the video will be flagged as violating TikTok’s rules against hateful rhetoric or violent content, deBuys said.

The shipment is part of UAE's ongoing humanitarian efforts to alleviate the suffering of the Palestinian people affected by the ongoing conflict and aims to support the global drive to provide humanitarian and relief aid to the Palestinian people.

It hasn't always been safe for you to show up and stay present.  In a moment of conflict, a young part of you might show up offering coping strategies that worked in the past - strategies that, while valid, are getting in the way of intimacy in the present.

We need to take these parts seriously.  This doesn't mean acting on them, it means listening.  Tuning in.  Offering them what was once so rare for them - attunement, responsiveness, non-judgment.

Once we have soothed those younger parts, we are better able to show up in our relationships in ways that are aligned with our values and desires.

#QST #QueerSexTherapy #Queer #Trauma  #RelationshipNeeds  #SexEd #SexTherapist #SexTherapy #YoungerSelf #Compassion #HealingYourInnerChild #SelfSoothing #EmotionalVulnerability

Amidst the chaos of war, our children at the Dr. Musa and Suhaila Nasir Pediatric Cancer Department in Gaza show unparalleled bravery. Unable to receive chemotherapy due to conflict, they channel their courage into art, creating messages of hope for the world. Despite the darkness, their vibrant drawings echo their unbroken spirits and dreams of peace. We extend heartfelt gratitude to the dedicated staff working tirelessly, providing love and care amidst extreme adversity. Please stand with these young heroes, sharing their stories of resilience and hope.

📸: Private Travis King, the US Army soldier who deserted his post and fled into North Korea earlier this year has now been officially charged.

King is being charged with desertion, assault on fellow soldiers, possessing a video of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct, soliciting a minor on Snapchat to create pornographic content, attempting to leave base after curfew, drinking alcohol against orders and other offenses.

“The man I raised, the man I dropped off at boot camp, the man who spent the holidays with me before deploying did not drink. A mother knows her son, and I believe something happened to mine while he was deployed. The Army promised to investigate what happened at Camp Humphrey's, and I await the results.”

#AJOPINION: "Dear Europeans," writes Majed Abusalama, Co-founder of Palestine Speaks in Germany.⁠
.⁠
"I, like millions of Palestinians, am living through the worst nightmare of yet another round of mass death and destruction unleashed on our people – something you would often simply call “an escalation” of the “Palestinian-Israeli conflict”.⁠
.⁠
Today, as I watch what is unfolding in my homeland, I feel qahr, but also deep indignation and frustration. The reactions of your leaders, dear Europeans, to what is going on have yet again revealed selective solidarity, moral failure and a dark double standard."⁠
.⁠

@revkevindeyoung writes: 
‘Faithful friends help each other with their words. “Oil and perfume make the heart glad, and the sweetness of a friend comes from his earnest counsel” (Prov. 27:9). The writer mentions two precious things in this proverb, oil and perfume, but neither are as precious as a wise friend.

We all know the proverb: “Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another” (Prov. 27:17). It’s a great word picture. Ask yourself: am I sponge that never hurts anyone, but never helps much either? Am I a sword that cuts to the quick but also destroys? Or am I a stone, the kind of friend upon which others can be sharpened, made better and more mature? Faithful friends make better stones than sponges or swords.

“Greater love has no one than this, that one lay down his life for his friends” (John 15:13). That means the greatest friend is the one who laid down the most for his friends. No question who this is.

To be sure, Jesus is more than a friend, but not less. He is the Divine Friend better than any other. He is never a fake friend, but always seeks our best. Neither is he a foul friend. He is slow to anger instead of quick to criticize. He is thoughtful and tender instead of annoying. He’s always trustworthy and never lets us down. Best of all, Jesus is a faithful friend. He not only sympathizes and comforts you in trouble, he delivers you from your greatest trouble, which is sin. Not only does he speak the truth and handle conflict, he made peace through his blood when were at enmity with him.  And he doesn’t just make us better, he makes us new. What a friend we have in Jesus, all our sins and griefs to bear. What a privilege to carry everything to him in prayer.’

Meta has apologised for adding "terr*rist" to the biographies of some Instagram users describing themselves as Palestinian.

Meta said it fixed a problem "that briefly caused inappropriate Arabic translations" in some of its products.

"We sincerely apologise that this happened,” said Meta. 

The platform has also faced accusations of suppressing content voicing support for Palestinians during the Israel-Gaza conflict.

Did you know that in 2016, many U.S. states passed laws that can punish you for boycotting Israel? These laws are called anti-BDS laws, and they are meant to protect Israel from boycotts. But some people think these laws are unfair and against the right to free speech. They have taken these laws to court and some judges have agreed with them. Other people think these laws are good and necessary to support Israel and fight antisemitism. They say these laws do not stop people from speaking, but only affect how they do business or spend money. There are also some people who want to make new rules at the national level that would support or enforce these state rules, or say that boycotting Israel is bad. But these rules have not become U.S. law yet. There are also some people who want to make new rules that would support a peaceful solution for the conflict between Israel and Palestinians, and say that Israel should stop occupying their land. But these rules have faced a lot of opposition from people who support Israel.

What do you think about these laws and the issues behind them? Share your thoughts in the comments below. #FreePalestine #AntiBDS #IsraelPalestine

Over the past month, Israel and Palestine have made international headlines for what is being recognized as a conflict between the Israeli army and the Palestinian militant group Hamas, after the October 7 bombing in Southern Israel that left 1,400 people dead. At least 3,400 people have been killed in Gaza and more than 12,000 have been injured in the wake of that night, according to the Palestinian Health Authority. The reactions across the globe have ranged widely and almost every country has expressed solidarity with either Israel or Palestine — who, as a result of the violence, have allies and enemies. Colombia, for example, officially declared its support for Palestine and likewise, pro-Palestine movements have grown throughout other countries in Latin America including Mexico and Venezuela.⁠
⁠
With the ongoing violence that’s led to the death of thousands of Israelis and Palestinians, the conflict has received global media coverage and gripped people on social media. As a result, there is a lot of confusion and misinformation rising as we are watching events unfold. It’s more important than ever that we are aware of what exactly is happening, the long history of events that led up to it, the historic ties between Palestine and Latin America, and how we as a community can show up. This is not meant to be a comprehensive guide but a starting place for education and allyship. Read on to learn more about the Free Palestine movement and how to help victims of the violence.⁠
⁠

A report by Reuters delves into recent arrests of Arab citizens in Israel due to their social media posts expressing solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza. ⁠
⁠
In one case, Palestinian singer and neuroscientist Dalal Abu Amneh filed a complaint with Israeli police after receiving death threats in response to her social media post. The post featured a Palestinian flag emoji and the words "There is no victor but God." According to Reuters, Israeli authorities accused her of promoting hate speech and incitement to her nearly 300,000 followers. She was detained for two days, placed under house arrest, and prohibited from discussing the conflict for 45 days.⁠
⁠
In another case, a 60-year-old urban planner faced arrest for posting a sketch and analysis of potential Israeli ground invasion scenarios into Gaza. According to Reuters, ground Invasion scenarios are discussed regularly in Israeli media.⁠
⁠
Israel has established a specialized task force focused on tracking and combating online incitement to terrorism. Police spokesperson Eli Levy revealed that this special team, formed in February, had spotted nearly 180 posts since October 7th. ⁠
⁠
Levy said that out of the 96 individuals under investigation, 63 of them had already been detained, "in some cases, within 40 minutes of the publication of a post".⁠
⁠
"Look at this audacity and ungratefulness. Citizens with a blue, Israeli ID... have the audacity to think that we as police will allow them to take to the streets and support a murderous, Nazi terrorist organization," he said.⁠
⁠
Hassan Jabareen, the director of the Haifa-based centre for Arab minority rights Adalah, told Reuters it knows of "at least 83 students who are facing disciplinary action at universities and that it received over 40 reports from employees who are at risk of being fired for social media posts expressing solidarity with Gaza."⁠
⁠
"About 90% of the cases, legally speaking, have no basis," said Jabareen. "The conduct of the police is illegal. You cannot arrest people over such things." ⁠
​⁠

Broadcasting regulator Ofcom was quick to suspend its director of online safety supervision, after her apparently “extreme” views on Israel’s war on Gaza were exposed.

On Monday, rightwing website Guido Fawkes reported that Fadzai Madzingira had been sharing her views on the conflict on her private Instagram account. Later that day Ofcom suspended her pending further investigation.

In an Instagram story Madzingira told of her “panic” and “hopelessness” at what is going on in the Middle East. “My acoount [sic.] has been chaotic for the last week bouncing between the continued targeting of Palenstinians [sic.] and dumb shit. Mostly because I could not process that we continue to act with surprise at what happens in an apartheid state…” she wrote.

Madzingira also liked a post by BLM UK, criticising the UK’s support for Israel as a “vile colonial alliance”, saying the decision to send Royal Navy ships to the Middle East is participating in “ethnic cleansing and genocide of Palestinians.”

Which bit of this is supposed to be shocking?

Amplifying @savethechildren’s and the UN’s message and adding a few thoughts. It’s hard not to express the sheer helplessness and sorrow many of us are experiencing right now.  So much has been said. So much more can be said. And whatever anyone says today, is always going to upset someone or the other simply because perspective is very personal for each individual. But there are some feelings we all share. At least I believe that. We all share a love for peace. For a decent life. We share the right to safety and freedom. And we share a common bond of empathy when others in our tribe are being harmed. 

The fact is we are all collectively grieving right now. For the people of Gaza who are in an unimaginable situation and don’t seem to have any recourse to safety. Their plight gets worse by the minute. People have lost everything. This needs to stop. 
We feel for the families of citizens of Israel who were killed and the hostages that are still being held and whose fate is unknown. 
The fact is all people have one thing in common. They belong to the human race. And through no individual fault of theirs they are now suffering terribly. 

Don’t tell me this conflict cannot be stopped by Israel using more peaceful methods. I refuse to believe that. If there was a collective will to stop this, with the help of all the other nations trying so desperately to prevent further escalation - it is possible. 

A country doesn’t become weaker by ending a war or an invasion or an aggression. In fact it’s the opposite. Ditto for Hamas. Any desire to wipe out anyone else is never going to work. Humanity over politics is the only way out. 

There just needs to be a willingness to do so.

I have some questions that I’ve been struggling to answer and I hope people can guide me in the right direction. Hope someone can relate.

Every morning when I wake up, one of the first things I think about is the conflict in Palestine and Israel. I immediately feel numb as this quiet sadness creeps in.

I ask myself how I can film myself putting on colourful makeup knowing the unimaginable suffering people are going through. Is it even appropriate? This leads me to two realisations.

The first is how powerless I am. I could want the same thing as what seems the entire world and that’s for the violence on innocents to end yet not know what you can actually do to help.

Make a social media post? Share a photo of the horrors we have all seen? Go to a protest? All of the above? What can I do as a genuine effort to help?

The second realisation is my immeasurable privilege. That’s because for the same people I lament for, all my questions are replaced by one that makes all of mine trite and empty. It’s because all they ask is “Will I live through the day?”.

That’s why I find myself quietly praying every day.  Not because I’m religious but because it feels like all I can really do.

Pray that we end this miserable cycle. Pray that we don’t lose any more innocents. Pray for a free Palestine 🇵🇸 

We are never truly free unless we all are ✌🏾

If we consider the conditions of destruction, it actually requires approximately 10,000 trucks. The occupation and the West allowed only 20 trucks, which is about 0.002% of what is required.

#War- Archbishop of Goa and Daman on Friday appealed the Christians to pray and fast for peace between Israel and Palestine on October 27

In a communication released here, Fr Ferrao said that in a world marred by conflict and suffering, the ongoing strife in Israel and Palestine stands as a stark reminder of the urgent need for peace in our world.

“We are witnessing a crisis that is claiming countless lives and causing immeasurable pain. Our Holy Father Francis is constantly voicing his concern for the humanitarian situation in Palestine and Israel, calling on all parties to lay down their weapons,” he said.

The Archbishop noted that speaking at his General Audience on the October 18, Fr Francis said “Lay down weapons and heed the cries for peace from the poor, the people, and the innocent children.

The Archbishop recalled that the Pope  called on all Christians to pray and fast for peace on Friday, October 27, 2023.

“He also encouraged people of other Christian denominations, other religions and all those who advocate for peace to participate as they see fit. The Pope

announced that the central event on Friday would be an hour of prayer at 6 pm in St. Peter’s Square, with the goal of invoking peace for the world,” Fr Ferrao said.

The Archbishop said that in response to our beloved Holy Father’s invitation, let us rise together and join him in observing coming Friday, the 27th of October, as a day of prayer, penance and fasting for peace in Israel and Palestine and between other war-torn countries and peoples.

“Prayer and penance can play a vital role in this endeavour. While we encourage individuals and families to join in this global spiritual exercise, we urge our Parish Priests, Chaplains, Heads of Institutions and of Religious Communities to organize for the people under their care at least an hour of prayer for this intention,” Fr Ferrao said.

From birth, we become attached to our parents, idolizing them as heroes and role models to follow and imitate. 

But as we grow older, we begin to question their ways and realize that they do not know everything. We begin to label them as controlling and abusing. 

In our teenage years, this judgement intensifies, leading to resentment in our adulthood.  We find ourselves blaming them for our traumas, relationships, and ingrained habits.

Yet, when we become parents, we repeat the patterns we once resented.  We slowly become what we judge and hate and the cycle repeats itself again. 

This is how trauma is passed on generation after generation. 

The moment you condemn a trait as undesirable, duality is created. When you judge your parents as controlling, your ego image of being non controlling is formed. 

All your controlling aspects become part of your shadow, hidden from conscious awareness. Then, without knowing you slowly become what you hate, you begin to control your diet, your schedule, your environment, your children.  It's all mechanical, there is no awareness.  Then, your children begin to judge and resent you, and unconsciously slowly begin to embody the same patterns. 

What if, instead, we paused to reflect on our childhood, viewing our parents through a lens of love and understanding rather than judgment?

It's in this shift that true healing emerges. Healing isn't about holding grudges or setting boundaries; those are merely ego responses to pain which lead to more suffering. 

To understand is to forgive. And when we forgive, we love.  That is a divine state of being which knows no separation, no pain, no conflict. You have the seed, just water it.

A dire warning has emerged from United Nations human rights experts regarding Israel’s actions in the ongoing conflict in Gaza. In a statement by members of the UN Human Rights Council Special Procedures body, the experts warned that Israel is engaged in a systematic campaign of crimes against humanity, raising concerns of potential genocide against the Palestinian people. ‘Considering statements made by Israeli political leaders and their allies, accompanied by military action in Gaza and escalation of arrests and killing in the West Bank, there is also a risk of genocide against the Palestine people,’ they said.

The group pointed to a series of troubling events, including the deadly airstrike targeting a hospital (which Israel has repeatedly denied), and several refugee shelters. Alongside military actions in Gaza, there has been an escalation of arrests and killings in the West Bank, contributing to the growing concern. These events notwithstanding, Israel has precipitated a humanitarian crisis with a ‘total blockade’ of Gaza, blocking access to food, fuel and medical supplies. The UN group denounced these tactics as ‘domicide,’ and claimed they are in direct violation of international law. The UN experts have demanded an immediate ceasefire, full access to essential provisions such as food, water, fuel, electricity, medicine, and shelter, and comprehensive measures for ‘reparation, restitution, and reconstruction to ensure full justice for Palestinians.’

When Gaza was bombed by Israel in 2014, the late architect Michael Sorkin was outraged by the devastation. He organized a project that invited designers to imagine a Gaza that was open and not devastated by war. @deensharp revisits their proposals. For Sorkin, at the heart of the conflict was a crisis of propinquity. He saw Israel’s separate and unequal provisioning of systems of water, sanitation, transportation, green space, and other infrastructure to Palestinians as an obvious and violent injustice that made it impossible for Israelis and Palestinians to understand each other and share space. His frustration was exacerbated by the fact that, as he had shown long ago in the case of Jerusalem, it was more than possible to plan an efficient and equitable shared city. Through his New York–based NGO, Terreform, a group of designers, environmentalists, planners, activists and scholars from Palestine, Israel, the U.S., UK, India and elsewhere responded to the brutality of Operation Protective Edge with ideas that look beyond Gaza as a site of bombing and deprivation. The result was a collection of projects and essays gathered together in the book, 'Open Gaza: Architectures of Hope.' In presenting its plan for a future Gaza, the contributors at Terreform, including Sorkin, admit that it comes out of a wild proposition: "One thinks very differently about Gaza … if its political border disappears as a physical fact."

Head to the link in our for a deeper look back at Terraform and other designers' proposals to reimagine Gaza as an open, shared territory connected to the broader world once again. 

Illustration: Courtesy of the AUC Press and Terreform

York University has issued a warning: if the institution’s student unions do not recant or sufficiently defend their collective statement on the Israel-Hamas conflict, they will risk losing their relationship with the university.

The university’s statement, released to the public on Friday, addressed the “serious and ongoing harms caused by [the groups’] statement,” which declares “solidarity with the Palestinian people” against “the settler-colonial apartheid state of so-called Israel.”

“Since 1948, Palestinian people have been systemically displaced from their land and homes as a result of state-sanctioned violence, siege, and genocide,” reads the student unions’ statement in part. “Our Unions remain unwavering in our support of the Palestinian people's fight for self-determination and liberation.”

In its statement, York University said the unions must retract the statement, issue an apology, acknowledge the impact of the statement on campus, and remove all union executives by 5 p.m. on Oct. 25.

Alternatively, the university said the student unions can challenge the assertion that the statement breached York’s Regulation Regarding Student Organizations by the same deadline.

You might think this is a no-brainer—obviously you’d speak up in favor of Sam, the candidate you think is the most qualified! But wait. Not so fast. You would after all be going against the grain. Your colleagues are all pretty enthusiastic about Robin. Are you *sure* Sam is the right choice? And even if you are certain Sam is the way to go, it could be a bit uncomfortable to challenge the group. Is it worth it? 🤔

An interesting psychological study found that in an experiment setting with only two candidates — Sam and Robin — participants were reluctant to speak up and more likely to passively let Robin be hired. But wait, what about that third candidate, Taylor? While Taylor might not be the most skilled candidate, floating their name in the discussion can make a crucial difference. In fact, the study found that in a setting where one person on the hiring team made a case for Taylor, this significantly increased the likelihood of participants advocating for Sam, the most promising candidate!

But why does one person speaking up in favor of Taylor have such an impact? It’s because throwing a minority opinion into the mix breaks up groupthink and pushes every member of the group to assess the situation for themselves. In other words, this challenges the group’s tendency to avoid conflict at all costs — and often leads to better decision-making! 🚀

Would you like to learn more about strategies for encouraging independent thinking, and why nonconformity is a strength we should nurture? Then we think you’ll like the Blink to “Originals” by author and organizational psychologist @adamgrant. In it, you’ll learn more about this experiment, but also about how Isaac Newton and Picasso came up with their most groundbreaking ideas! 💥

The Cycle of Life
-
The personality consists of the transitory vehicles through which the Thinker energizes in the Physical, Astral, and lower Mental worlds, and of all the activities connected with these. These are bound together by the links of memory caused by impressions made on the three lower bodies; and, by the self-identification of the Thinker with his vehicles, the personal "I" is set up. The personality, with its transient feelings, desires, passions, thus forms a quasi-independent entity, though drawing all its energies from the Thinker it enwraps, and as its qualifications, belonging to the lower worlds, are often in direct antagonism to the permanent interests of the "Dweller in the body," conflict is set up in which victory inclines sometimes to the temporary pleasure, sometimes to the permanent gain.
-
The individuality consists of the Thinker himself, the immortal tree that puts out all these personalities as leaves, to last through the spring, summer, and autumn of human life. All that the leaves take in and assimilate enriches the sap that courses through their veins, and in the autumn this is withdrawn into the parent trunk, and the dry leaf falls and perishes. The Thinker alone lives forever; he is the man for whom "the hour never strikes," the eternal youth who, as the Bhagavad Gita has it, puts on and casts off bodies as a man puts on new garments and throws off the old. Each personality is a new part for the immortal Actor, and he treads the stage of life over and over again, only in the life-drama each character he assumes is the child of the preceding ones and the father of those to come, so that the life-drama is a continuous history, the history of the Actor who plays the successive parts.

This is a very difficult time – we can help each other

The situation is tense in the region. Our thoughts are with the people suffering and most affected. 

We are witnessing horrific suffering of innocent lives, the disappearance of humanity.

We are sad, we are stressed, we are scared - mostly we feel helpless. Each hour that goes by brings a possibility of conflict spilling over.

In four years we suffered through economic crisis, nationwide protests, shortage of food, electricity, fuel, medication, hyperinflation. Coronavirus. Terrible Beirut explosion. More protests, a full year with no government. Many went through the 2006 war and helped animals. We did not imagine we would reach this level of atrocities.

We have to be strong – not for us but for the animals that depend on us. We have over 100 cats and dogs, two young lions, six baboons, and other wildlife we are working on. Lions scheduled to leave to a sanctuary in South Africa, baboons to a sanctuary in the UK, cats and dogs to various countries. These trips are now at risk and we fear they might be stuck.

We are now receiving dozens of requests per day for help with people leaving Lebanon with their pets. We are helping make sure they have the right documents and permits, buy traveling cages, making flight reservations, or updating veterinary records so they are prepared in case they need to leave suddenly. You can check the travel guidelines in our previous post.

We are trying to build up a three-to-six-month supply for our own animals and so we can help the community.

We have to be prepared in case the situation gets worse.

"Madly in Love" is a captivating tale of love transcending social boundaries and personal dreams. This novel, set in the backdrop of Gorakhpur, revolves around two compelling characters: Meera, a young girl born into privilege, and Mohan, a diligent and ambitious boy aspiring to crack the Civil Services exam.

The story skillfully delves into the complexities of love across caste and class divides. Meera's bold choice to love a boy from another caste challenges the deep-rooted social norms and her family's influential status. The central question of whether her family will continue to support her is a thread that keeps readers engaged throughout the narrative.

Mohan's character is portrayed with honesty and determination, making readers empathize with his struggle to balance his aspirations with his love for Meera. The conflict between pursuing his dream and confronting social barriers adds depth to his character and showcases the internal battles faced by many young individuals in similar situations.

The narrative is marked by emotional turmoil, threats to their lives, and the constant pressure from society and families. This emotional rollercoaster resonates with readers and adds an element of suspense, keeping them invested in the fate of the two protagonists.

The author, through intricate storytelling, provides a realistic portrayal of the challenges faced by Meera and Mohan. Their unwavering commitment to each other, even in the face of adversity, reflects the power of love. The book masterfully portrays how love can redefine destinies and push individuals to overcome obstacles they never thought possible.

"Madly in Love" is a poignant and moving story that touches on themes of love, sacrifice, societal expectations, & personal dreams. It provides a thought-provoking exploration of the complexities of modern relationships and challenges readers to reflect on the power of love in reshaping lives.

In summary, this novel is a compelling and emotionally charged narrative that will resonate with readers who appreciate stories of love's triumph over adversity. It offers a fresh perspective on societal norms & the enduring strength of love for romance lovers.

Recently, we have witnessed horrific violence and loss of life in Israel and Gaza, impacting communities in the Middle East, the United States, Latin America, and throughout the world. Aligned with the Museum’s core values, El Museo del Barrio supports and upholds human rights, and the peaceful resolution of this conflict.

During these fraught times, we continue to host visitors and artists of diverse and differing beliefs and viewpoints through our doors. El Museo del Barrio is, and will remain, a cultural institution for all members of our community regardless of gender, political convictions, cultural identity, sexual orientation, and religious beliefs. 

Our sympathies go out to those who are directly, or indirectly by way of diaspora or heritage, affected by the conflict. We encourage museum visitors to donate to a trusted charity of their choice dedicated to those most affected during this difficult time.

We urge our world leaders to present a resolution to this conflict so that human rights and dignity can be preserved. 

Thank you for your support,

Patrick Charpenel
Executive Director
El Museo del Barrio

Earlier this year, the United Nations oversaw a complex operation to remove more than 1 million barrels of crude oil from the FSO Safer, a decaying vessel off the coast of Yemen.

For years, efforts to neutralize the threat from the Safer had come up empty — because of the war, disagreements over how the oil should be secured and struggles to raise funding. A renewed effort in 2020 proposed to transfer the oil off the ship to another tanker, rather than securing it in place.

The complex initiative required the purchase of an oil tanker, the hiring of a salvage company and coordination between bitter foes on opposite sides of Yemen’s conflict.

🔥 How to Handle the "Condemn Hamas" Question 🇵🇸

In the midst of the complex and heart-wrenching situation in Palestine and Gaza, you might find yourself faced with the challenging question: "Do you condemn Hamas?" Here's what you need to know and how to respond:

1. **Stay Informed**: Start by understanding the context and the situation on the ground. Knowledge is power, and it will help you form a well-informed opinion.

2. **Refuse to be Cornered**: Don't allow yourself to be forced into a corner where you have to make an unfair choice. It's not black and white.

3. **No Rush to Judgment**: Avoid hasty condemnations. Without the full story and all the facts, it's unwise to pass judgment on complex issues.

4. **Principled Stand**: You can be critical of actions and policies without endorsing terrorism. Make it clear that you stand for peace, human rights, and justice.

5. **Question the Question**: Challenge the framing of the question. It's often a trap, designed to oversimplify a multifaceted conflict.

6. **Educate and Advocate**: Use this as an opportunity to raise awareness about the larger issues at hand - the rights and lives of those affected by the conflict.

7. **Engage in Dialogue**: Encourage open, respectful dialogue to foster understanding, even with those who may have different perspectives.

Credits @halalstockok

🎉 New Affiliate Project: The Papua New Guinea Manta Project 🇵🇬

We are thrilled to introduce our latest affiliate project, The Papua New Guinea Manta Project (PNGMP)! 🇵🇬

🌊 Their aim is to better understand the population dynamics of manta and devil rays throughout the Milne Bay Province and across Papua New Guinea region, in order to support local capacity building by working hand-in-hand with local NGOs throughout the region. 

🏆 Their current achievements include: conducting ongoing training and field trips with the Sea Women of Melanesia and collaborated with the Coral Sea Foundation to incorporate valuable manta research into their programme. They also conducted a feasibility study in partnership with the Manta Trust and the Conflict Islands Conservation Initiative to increase the knowledge of the manta rays in this remote biodiversity hotspot. 

🤿 This project was established by project leader, Dr. Annie Murray. She aims to learn more about this understudied population of manta rays, building on previous research conducted in the region to answer the many questions regarding their population dynamics and population movements, whilst maintaining a strong focus on supporting local researchers and communities.

💙 Thank you to all those who have supported and donated to the project, with a special thanks to @sandrinapostorino ! 

📲 Join us in celebrating the launch of The Papua New Guinea Manta Project (PNGMP)! Learn more about PNGMP and our other affiliate projects, by clicking the link in our bio! 

@seawomenofmelanesia @coralseafoundation @conflictislands @cici_png_

Lokesh Kanagaraj’s Leo starts with an acknowledgment that it’s inspired by A History of Violence (2005), the David Cronenberg action thriller based on John Wagner’s graphic novel of the same title. The story of a seemingly peaceful man with a secret, violent history is common enough. The contrast between the characters allows for a cinematic explosion of heroism, a high you experience even if you were expecting it all along. What makes these stories about ‘bad boys turned good’ fascinating is their internal conflict and how they confront the shadows of the past that catch up with them eventually.

Leo’s Parthiban, an animal rescuer, leads a perfect life – a loving wife (Trisha), a son with whom he shares a friendly rapport (Matthew Thomas), and a daughter who adores him (Iyal). When an incident at his restaurant brings back ghosts from his past, he goes all out to protect his family. Lokesh says he is a man who is capable of much love and tenderness. Can he really be a killer?

Addressing a Cairo summit as the conflict raged into its third week, Guterres said the Palestinian enclave of 2.4 million people was living through “a humanitarian catastrophe” with thousands dead and more than a million displaced.

“We meet in the heart of a region that is reeling in pain and one step from the precipice,” he told the meeting that included the leaders of Egypt, Iraq, Jordan and the United Arab Emirates as well as of Italy and Spain and Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas.

The bloodshed began on October 7 when Hamas militants stormed across the Gaza border into Israel, launching an attack that has killed more than 1,400 people, mostly civilians, in the deadliest attack on Israeli soil since the state was founded in 1948.

Israel has hit back with a relentless bombing campaign, killing more than 4,300 Palestinians, mainly civilians according to Gaza’s Hamas-run health ministry.

Guterres said “the grievances of the Palestinian people are legitimate and long” after “56 years of occupation with no end in sight” but stressed that “nothing can justify the reprehensible assault by Hamas that terrorised Israeli civilians”.

Apa itu hukum humaniter internasional? Hukum humaniter internasional adalah seperangkat aturan yang, karena alasan kemanusiaan dibuat untuk membatasi akibat-akibat dari pertikaian senjata.

Hukum ini melindungi mereka yang tidak atau tidak lagi terlibat dalam pertikaian, dan membatasi cara-cara dan metode berperang. Hukum Humaniter Internasional adalah istilah lain dari hukum perang (laws of war) dan hukum konflik bersenjata (laws of armed conflict).

Hukum humaniter ini diciptakan tidak dimaksudkan untuk melarang perang, atau untuk mengadakan undang-undang yang menentukan permainan "perang", tetapi karena alasan-alasan perikemanusiaan untuk mengurangi atau membatasi penderitaan individu-individu dan untuk membatasi wilayah dimana kebuasan konflik bersenjata diperbolehkan. (heylaw.id)

Roman-era mosaic is uncovered during the excavation of an old building in Syria .

RASTAN, Syria —in 2022 Syria uncovered a large intact mosaic that dates back to the Roman era, describing it Wednesday as the most important archaeological discovery since the country's conflict began 11 years ago.

Journalists were shown the mosaic in the central town of Rastan near Homs, Syria's third largest city.

The mosaic, at 120 square meters (around 1,300 square feet), was found in an old building that Syria's General Directorate of Antiquities and Museums had been excavating.

Lebanese and Syrian businessmen from the neighboring country's Nabu Museum bought the property that dates back to the 4th century and donated it to the Syrian state.

Each panel was filled with square-shaped, small colorful stones measuring about half an inch on each side.

Dr. Humam Saad, the associate director of excavation and archaeological research at the directorate, said among the scenes the mosaic shows is a rare portrayal of Ancient Amazon warriors in Roman mythology.

"What is in front of us is a discovery that is rare on a global scale," Saad told The Associated Press, adding that the images are "rich in details," and includes scenes from the Trojan War between the Greeks and Trojans.

In Ancient Greek and Roman mythology, demigod hero Hercules slayed Hippolyta, queen of the Amazons, in one of his 12 labors.

Source : NPR website
📸 Omar Sanadiki
1 - 2 Edit : @archaeology.news

The German and Dutch governments have deployed Special Forces units to Cyprus as they prepare for potential crisis situations in Israel, Gaza and West Asia.

The German Army’s Special Forces Command (KSK), Navy Special Forces (KSM) unit, also known as combat swimmers, and the federal police Special Forces unit, which specializes in rescuing hostages (GSG 9), were all deployed to the Mediterranean island nation, the Bild reported on 19 October, citing security sources.

According to Bild, Berlin is preparing for “all scenarios” should the conflict between the Hamas-led Palestinian resistance and Israel escalate.

As 20 aid trucks arrived at a UN storage facility in central Gaza on Saturday, October 21, uncertainty loomed for the 2.3 million people still blockaded there.

It’s been two weeks since Hamas attacked Israel, killing close to 1,400 people in coordinated attacks that prompted devastating Israeli retaliation and increased tensions around the world. 

Israel said it would its increase strikes on Gaza, starting Saturday.

Hamas is holding as many as 200 hostages it kidnapped during the attacks, and says 50 more captives are being held by other armed groups inside Gaza.

Hamas previously said 20 hostages were killed by Israeli air strikes, without providing details.

Two American hostages were released by Hamas Friday and handed over to Israeli authorities after Qatar helped mediate their release. 

In addition to Israeli hostages, Hamas is also holding citizens of Thailand, Argentina, Britain, Germany, France and Portugal.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed ‘mighty vengeance’ for the Oct. 7 massacre. A ground invasion of Gaza by Israeli forces could come at any time. 

More than 4300 Palestinian people, including women and children, have been killed in the retaliatory attacks.

Demonstrations around the world show deep divisions in communities supporting Palestinian and Israeli civilians.

The U.S. has affirmed support for Israel’s right to defend itself, but officials have expressed doubt that Israel has crafted an endgame to the conflict that threatens to draw in other countries and divide the world.

Arab leaders at a Cairo summit on Saturday condemned the Israeli bombardment of Gaza. With Israel and the U.S. absent from the summit, no agreement was made toward how to contain the violence.

Gulf Cooperation Council and ASEAN countries called for a durable ceasefire, the immediate release of civilian hostages and detainees, and a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

China’s special envoy on Middle East affairs has also called for efforts to implement a two-state solution and promote an early, comprehensive, just, and lasting settlement of the Palestinian question.

22 journalists killed since H~mas-Israel conflict erupted

New York, Oct 21: The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based nonprofit, has said that at least 22 journalists have been killed since the H~mas launched its massive assault on !srael on October 7.

In a report released on Friday, the CPJ said that it is investigating all reports of journalists killed, injured, detained, or missing in the raging conflict, including those hurt as hostilities spread to neighboring Leban0n.

“As of October 20, at least 22 journalists were among the more than 4,000 dead on both sides since the war began on October 7, with hundreds killed in Tuesday’s hospital blast in Ga~a,” it said.

“Journalists in Ga~a face particularly high risks as they try to cover the conflict in the face of a ground assault by Israel! troops, devastating Israel! airstrikes, disrupted communications, and extensive power outages.”

Of the 22 slain journalists, 18 were Palest!n!an, three Israel!s and one Lebanese.

While eight reporters were injured, three others have been reportedly missing or detained.

The CPJ said that it was probing “numerous unconfirmed reports of other journalists being killed, missing, detained, hurt or threatened, and of damage to media offices and journalists’ homes”.

“CPJ emphasizes that journalists are civilians doing important work during times of crisis and must not be targeted by warring parties,” said Sherif Mansour, CPJ’s Middle East and North Africa program coordinator.

“Journalists across the region are making great sacrifices to cover this heartbreaking conflict. All parties must take steps to ensure their safety.”

The nonprofit stressed that it remained unclear whether all of the slain journalists were covering the conflict at the time of their deaths.–(IANS)

“A lot of people ask me if I feel safe now that I'm back in New York. I don't. A lot of the things I've been hearing and seeing since getting back. A lot of the videos of the protests. These pro-Palestinian protests. Something I would like to say about that is, whatever side you're on in regards to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, all the power to you. But this is not about Israel-Palestine. This is about Hamas, a terrorist organization who is just as complicit in the deaths of these innocent Palestinians as they are in the deaths of innocent Israelis."

Natalie said this is not about Israel vs. Palestine. This is about a terrorist organization attacking the Jews and killing innocent people, killing innocent people at a music festival, killing innocent grandmas who survived the Holocaust, just to be killed by Hamas, burning babies alive.

“The amount of antisemitism I've seen in videos since coming back to New York, antisemitism all over Europe and the United States, that scares me more than anything. For so long, as a Jew growing up in America, you're always taught about the Holocaust, and you're taught about the way our people were treated and the way so many people just stood by and watched as the Holocaust happened. And you're taught to never forget. And my whole life, I tried to understand how could — how could the world stand by? How could the world stand by and let that happen? And it's sad to say that I'm now starting to realize how. And I don't feel safe." 

The security at the festival was very tight, something her three friends who were there with her were accustomed to. But they woke up to the sounds of rockets. They ran as far as they could away from the festival.

A group of people encouraged her friends to join them in hiding in a ditch, but they declined, fearing that if terrorists were to arrive, they'd have no way out. She later learned that those who stayed there had all been killed.

They were eventually picked up by a local man from the town Patish, who left the security of his town and drove toward the terrorists. 

“He risked his own life to try to save our lives." He went back to get more people. Natalie never had a chance to thank him.

The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) on Friday said Israeli forces threatened to bomb the Al-Quds Hospital in the Gaza Strip, which is sheltering thousands of displaced women and children.

As many as "12,000 displaced people, including 70% children and women, are in imminent danger after Israeli forces threatened to bomb Al-Quds Hospital and demanded evacuation," the humanitarian organization said on X.

"This place could turn to ashes if those threats are carried out."

"Is there a world power capable of stopping the threats of the Israeli occupation army to bomb hospitals with innocent civilians inside?" the PRCS said.

It called on the international community to "act urgently" to avert "another catastrophe like Al-Ahli Hospital."

At least 471 people were killed and many others injured in the Israeli airstrike on Al-Ahli Baptist Hospital earlier this week, according to health officials in Gaza. Israel, however, denied responsibility for the air raid.

The ongoing deadly conflict began Oct. 7 when Hamas initiated Operation Al-Aqsa Flood -- a multi-pronged surprise attack that included a barrage of rocket launches and infiltrations into Israel by land, sea and air.

Hamas said the incursion was in retaliation for the storming of the Al-Aqsa Mosque and growing violence by Israeli settlers.

The Israeli military then launched Operation Swords of Iron against Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip.

In addition to launching a sweeping bombardment campaign ahead of an expected ground invasion, Israel ordered a "full siege" on Gaza that has led to electricity supplies being severed as water, food, fuel and medical supplies run out.

“Approach plugged culvert as a water problem, not a beaver problem.” -Former MDIFW Wildlife Technician, Jim Dorso

When humans see a road with a culvert in a wetland, they see a path across, but a beaver sees a dam with a leak. Plugged culverts are the most common conflict with beavers.

Simply removing a beaver would only be a temporary fix until another beaver comes along to use the same habitat and fix the same leak. Removal of beaver would also eliminate an integral component of healthy aquatic ecosystems. Beavers are ecosystem engineers whose behavior modifies habitat, creating space and resources for countless other species.

Site modification is an alternative approach which produces long-term and cost-effective solutions for chronic problems by simultaneously addressing current conflict and minimizing future conflict, all while preserving quality wetland habitat produced by beavers.

Seen here, MDIFW and USDA biologists train @university.of.maine students in the implementation of a site modification device known as a beaver deceiver. This device denies access to culverts which maintains normal water flow and eliminates the need for constant maintenance. It also encourages dam placement upstream from the culvert and maintains a water level that is acceptable for both humans and beavers. Everybody wins!

For more information about preventing conflict with beavers while maintaining wetlands, visit mefishwildlife.com/livingwithwildlife

#BeaverDeceiver #LivingWithWildlife #Maine #KeeperOfME #BusyBeaver

Hi. I’m Lindsey Lanza and I’m proud to be a Jewish author of happy books that spread joy 🩵

I haven’t been very vocal or active on social media recently, but while I did my best to avoid conflict, it found me.

𝗟𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗻𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗜 𝗿𝗲𝗰𝗲𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗱 𝗮 𝗗𝗠 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗮𝗶𝗱: “𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙖 𝙕𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙞𝙨𝙩? 𝙄’𝙢 𝙢𝙖𝙠𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙖 𝙡𝙞𝙨𝙩 𝙤𝙛 𝙖𝙪𝙩𝙝𝙤𝙧𝙨 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙥𝙧𝙤 𝙜𝙚𝙣𝙤𝙘𝙞𝙙𝙚”

I did not engage with this person and immediately blocked/reported them. But after letting their message sync in I can’t be silent anymore.

Being a Zionist means believing that Israel should 𝑒𝑥𝑖𝑠𝑡. 𝗧𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗶𝘁. It doesn’t mean you agree with their government just like being an American doesn’t mean you agree with our government. I’m sick of people being villainized for using this word bc if you don’t think Israel should exist then you might as well say Jews shouldn’t exist. 

But I’m not even here to address their question bc it’s offensive and ridiculous. What concerns me the most is that someone I don’t know reached out to me solely because I’m Jewish and basically threatened to put me on a list. 

A list for what? Is my name now floating around as a precaution to readers? Are my books being banned bc they mention latkes and matzah ball soup? Will this post get me on more lists? Probably 🤷🏻‍♀️

If it really needs to be stated, I’m horrified by what’s happening in Israel and Gaza. Loss of life from any nation, religion or ethnic group is devastating. But why have we turned their conflict into our own? Why are so many people using this as a way to spread more hate and more violence? 

If you have felt the need to send a DM like the one I got last night, or to “make a statement” about a war happening across the world, I implore you to ask yourself why. And to think about the repercussions of your actions.

Spread love, not hate. Read more romance 🩵✡️

'I was greatly tempted by Sam Leith’s suggestion in a column on The Spectator’s website this week that we should all shut up about Israel and Palestine because we don’t know what we’re talking about. Certainly the crisis there has made London dinner parties almost unendurable – and it is true that as soon as anyone brings up Sykes-Picot, which they always do, I begin to choke on my baba ganoush and start demanding that the host open another bottle of Fairtrade Palestinian pinot noir. But then I thought that if in future I wrote about only those things of which I have a perfect understanding, pace Wittgenstein, I’d be well and truly buggered as a columnist. 

'Old Ludwig didn’t think about that, did he? A lack of expertise has never stopped me weighing in with a jiffy bag of bile on every subject under the sun and I don’t see why Jews and Arabs should be exempt. Further, while I daresay my understanding of Middle Eastern politics is woefully incomplete, I have always tended to be on the side of civilisation when it is opposed by medieval barbarity. In making this choice, I consider myself progressive as well as – Ludwig, take note – both logical and positive. 

'This article is not about Israel and Palestine, as it happens, but about the way in which the narrative regarding that conflict is being carefully marshalled by our institutions. The BBC, with its – on the face of it – hilarious decision not to call Hamas ‘terrorists’, you will be well aware of; much as you will of the entirely justified protest outside New Broadcasting House. But the hi-tech social media giants are another issue entirely. I know you know this, but we have to keep an eye on these bastards, remembering their gleeful distortion of the narrative during the last US presidential election: the deliberate suppression of stories that might be damaging to the Biden campaign and finally the removal of the then president from all social media outlets so that he no longer had a voice. If they do that to presidents, what might they do to the rest of us?'

✍️ Rod Liddle: Facebook’s not-so-secret police 

🔗 Link to full article in bio

It’s been a very somber last week in parliament. It’s not just the suffering and dying in war zones that sickens and terrifies me, it’s what is born there. Seeds are sown for more conflict, more cruelty, more suffering, for generations to come. That’s why war and violence is never the answer. I felt this strongly when I visited the battlefields of World War 1. A lingering sense of evil - the only time in my life I’d use this word as a best description. Seems we never learn the lessons of history. If you are a 16 year old in #gaza you have now seen 6 wars in your short life. That’s desperately sad, and a warning to us all about how intractable this conflict has become. A conflict that could not only draw in other middle eastern powers (as has been the case 5 times over the past 75 years) but risks becoming global. The Greens are a party of peace and non violence, that’s one big reason I joined them. We condemn all violence, war crimes, especially against civilians in wars. By anyone- we don’t take sides on this principle. There has to be a better way forward to end the seemingly endless impasse of violence, occupation, suffering, war crimes - rather than the expected wholesale destruction of a city that has millions of occupants, 40% of them children. Binary ‘with us or against us’ political messaging is offensive and should be rejected, and makes more bloodshed inevitable, today and into the future. ‘Peace through superior firepower’ as a paradigm has obviously not secured a lasting peace for Israel. Where does it end? I’ll continue to share important updates to my story from the @unitednations and other trusted information sources on this unfolding human catastrophe in and around Gaza, and what you can do. As much as it’s understandable- human nature to turn away when it all becomes too much for us to see, bear, we simply can’t. There is way too much at stake, we need to call for a ceasefire, humanitarian aid, and peace talks that offer hope for long term resolutions. #palestine #israel

The first humanitarian aid convoy to be sent to the besieged Gaza Strip since war broke out there began moving through the Rafah border crossing from Egypt on Saturday after days of diplomatic wrangling over conditions for delivering the relief.

The United Nations said the 20-truck convoy included life-saving supplies that would be received by the Palestinian Red Crescent. Palestinian group Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, said the delivery included medicine and limited amounts of food.

Rafah is the main route in and out of the Gaza Strip that is not controlled by Israel, and the focus of efforts to deliver aid to Gaza's 2.3 million residents.

U.N. officials say at least 100 trucks a day are needed in Gaza to cover urgent needs, and that any delivery of aid needs to be sustained and at scale. Before the outbreak of conflict, an average of about 450 aid trucks were arriving there daily.

Kaala Paani gets one thing so well - any story set in the middle of a crisis outbreak, becomes a map built of many human stories. The general conflict is between human survival or loss, and that rests on the smaller stories of individual characters we care for. Every larger human debate plays out in the intimacy of a few individuals.

Set in the middle of a rare illness outbreak in the Andaman islands, Kaala Paani does something similar by intricately threading many such stories - there are the individuals representing the medical side grappling with the crisis, which has its own conflicts of who stands up for the fight, who is more caught up with selfish concerns (Mona Singh stands out with a role that is brief but throws huge shadows of her presence through every episode). 

There's the side of civilians, which always makes for the most heartbreaking stories - made up of separations, searches, loss, they are the heart of the story. I was incredibly moved by the story of Santosh and Gargi's family - the third episode made me tear up, even the name of the third episode has such a powerful reveal later when you realise it. 

Like the best such stories, Kaala Paani doesn't sensationalize these stories but humanizes them through various perspectives. Strongly recommended it!

#KaalaPaaniOnNetflix

Disclaimer, this is about relationships with normal, day to day issues and misunderstandings. This is not about accepting abusive behavior. That’s a different story.

When you’re married or in a committed relationship, there’s always going to be disagreements, differing opinions, and conflict. It’s natural because we all have our own set of beliefs, and problems. 

When these conflicts and issues occur, don’t start looking at other women, or ladies, don’t start looking at other men and think “he would be so much better for me, my man is a jerk. Or for the men, “she would treat me better than my girl, my girl is just a bitch”. Remember, they also have their own issues, character flaws, and difficulties.

Stop looking at “someone else” through rose colored glasses because you’re going through a rough patch in your marriage or relationship. And start looking at your partner with rose colored glasses. Find the beauty in them, and the reasons you chose them. 

Because to be married, or in a relationship is really just choosing one persons flaws over everyone else’s. You may be exchanging someone with issues you can live, for someone whose issues may destroy you mentally and emotionally.

Don’t do something stupid now that you may very well regret later.

Therefore, If you’re going to look at anyone through rose colored glasses, make it your partner. 

We all have issues, we all have problems, and we all have insecurities, none of us are perfect. Don’t expect your partner to be.

Smash the “like” button and comment. I would love to hear your thoughts.

Parts Unknown - Season 2, Episode 1: “Jerusalem”

The central subjects of Anthony Bourdain’s programs increasingly shifted from highlighting world cuisines to the people and cultural conflicts across our globe — stories that he felt a profound responsibility to tell, but also took an enormous toll on his personal struggles in a way that is now soberingly obvious. But these programs were also an enormous contribution to humanity, providing a way for many of us to attempt to understand other parts of our world and empathize with humanity's struggles. And that feels a particular imperative today. 

As Bourdain put it: "One can be forgiven for thinking, when you see how similar they are, the two peoples, both of them cook with pride, eat with passion, love their kids, love the land in which they live or the land they dream of returning to, who live so close, who are locked in such an intimate, if deadly embrace, might somehow, some day, figure out how to live with each other. But that would be very mushy thinking indeed. Those things in the end probably don't count for much at all."

Goodness, do these words sting ever more acutely with the reality of this conflict just 10 years later.

In no way will we attempt to explain or make sense of this terrible conflict that we are witnessing in the middle east. But we do recommend taking 43 minutes to watch this short episode as we did this morning. 

All of our love to those who are hurting most.
