What happened: United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres visited the Rafah border crossing between Egypt and the Gaza Strip on October 20, 2023, in an effort to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid to the besieged Palestinian enclave.

Details: During his visit, Guterres engaged with various parties, including Egypt, Israel, and the United States, to expedite the movement of aid trucks into Gaza. The exact timeline for the delivery of relief materials stockpiled in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula remained uncertain at the time of his visit. Guterres emphasized the importance of swift and sustained aid delivery, characterizing these trucks as a lifeline and a matter of life and death for the people in Gaza. The international community is actively working to make this happen despite the challenges posed by the conflict and the need for secure and effective aid distribution, he added.

What you need to know: The situation in Gaza is dire, with most of its 2.3 million inhabitants heavily reliant on humanitarian aid due to a longstanding blockade imposed by Israel and Egypt since 2007. Before the recent conflict, around 450 aid trucks were entering Gaza daily, but the situation deteriorated following the hostilities between Israel and Hamas. Efforts are ongoing to ensure a substantial and sustainable aid operation to address the urgent needs of Gaza's people.

“Black American and Palestinian solidarity is not only rooted in struggle but hope, fighting, resilience, laughter, endless battling, sadness, and doing it all over again the next day. “In a lot of ways, it was your use of the kishōtenketsu early on in your own work that served as a model for what a narrative can look like if conflict isn’t the crux of the narrative. What if the tension that exists in the narrative is simply the passage of time, or the proximity of characters to one another? Which is a little bit antagonistic to the way so many of us have been taught in white contemporary American literary fiction. But I think that in writing narratives featuring queer folks who are coming from marginalized communities, who among us is certain? Who among us feels as if we are the voice, or have the solution at any given moment? For these characters, for my own life, so much comes from the collective. On the level of prose, that meant trying to give as much credence to each speaker in the text as possible. If the motion is to try to paint a simulacrum of lived experience as possible on the page, trying to allow the community of voices and a communal arc felt as if it were more fitting not only for this particular narrative but for the characters I was circling around.” - Bryan Washington to Ocean Vuong on the structure of the narrative in his novel, Family Meal

Whitney Pocket Model Second Model Second Type in .31 Caliber with a 4” barrel 

The Whitney Pocket Model classification includes a variety of small caliber revolvers with the earliest one came on the scene around 1850, followed by a series of improved revolvers . As indicated by the name, these “pocket” revolvers were designed to be easily carried by civilians.  They are primarily .31 caliber revolvers, with a few models made in .28 caliber and they came with barrel lengths between 3”-6”. The Pocket models would also differ with their loading levers either being a ball type latch (like the one shown) or a Colt wedge style latch.

Whitney, and other firearms manufacturers struggled to produce reliable “revolvers” during the early 1850s with Sam Colt’s patent on his revolving mechanism did not expire until 1857.  Prior to that time, Whitney and others had to offer alternative methods of turning the cylinder.  After the patent expired, Whitney was ready with his .36 Navy Model revolver and a Pocket Model that closely resembled the Navy Model. Revolvers like the Pocket Model would’ve been bought privately during the American Civil War by troops on both sides of the conflict due to handguns not being fully standard issue for all troops. 

Photo taken by- @grey.wolf.tactical

text:
In a statement, Egyptian authorities said that the summit aims to push for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza after relentless Israeli bombardment killed about 4,000 Palestinians and injured more than 13,000.

The hastily convened talks, which will bring together international and regional leaders, will explore ways to protect civilians from the violence and reach a just solution to the Palestinian issue.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi called the summit as an agreement was reached with Israel to allow 20 trucks of aid per day through the Rafah border crossing in a bid to prevent a humanitarian crisis.

Regional leaders expected to attend include Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, Jordan’s King Abdullah II, Bahrain’s King Hamad bin Isa Al-Khalifa, Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani and Kuwaiti Crown Prince Sheikh Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah.

A list of international attendees includes Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, Cypriot President Nikos Christodoulides, German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock, French Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna, Japanese Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa and UK Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs James Cleverly.

15 Palestinians, in new Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.

At least 15 Palestinians, including four children, were killed in renewed Israeli airstrikes on the Gaza Strip, the Gaza Interior Ministry said Saturday.

A statement said 10 were killed when Israeli fighter jets struck two houses in Deir al-Balah in central Gaza.

And four children and a woman were killed in a separate strike on a house east of Rafah in southern Gaza, it said

The conflict in Gaza, under Israeli bombardment and blockade since Oct. 7, began when Hamas initiated Operation Al-Aqsa Flood -- a multi-pronged surprise attack that included a barrage of rocket launches and infiltrations into Israel by land, sea and air.

Hamas said the incursion was in retaliation for the storming of the Al-Aqsa Mosque and growing violence by Israeli settlers.

The Israeli military then launched Operation Swords of Iron against Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip, putting the territory's 2.3 million residents under total siege and a blockade of food, fuel and medical supplies

UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres urged an "immediate humanitarian cease-fire" to ease the "epic human suffering."

At least 4,137 Palestinians, including 1,524 children and 1,000 women have been killed in Israeli attacks on Gaza. That figure stands at more than 1,400 in Israel

李显龙总理指出，以色列不能只为宣泄情绪而展开报复攻击，因为这反而会让自己陷入更糟糕的境地。

他也重申，通过谈判达成让巴勒斯坦人和以色列人和平共处、安全生活的两国方案，是打破暴力循环，实现持久和平的唯一可行途径。“如果以巴不朝这个方向努力，恐怕注定会经历世世代代的流血和悲剧。我认为双方都不希望发生这种情况。”

李总理应沙特阿拉伯王储穆罕默德邀请，从10月17日至20日进行访问。期间，他在利雅得出席首次召开的亚细安—海湾合作委员会（Gulf Cooperation Council，简称海合会）峰会，与两个地区的领导人讨论全球和区域局势，包括不断升级的以哈冲突。海合会成员为沙特、科威特、阿联酋、卡塔尔、巴林和阿曼。

李总理在结束四天行程前，接受随行媒体访问。他说，每当发生人道主义危机，总会引起国际社会关注，尤其当遭受苦难的是无辜平民、婴儿、儿童和年长者。以最近的以哈冲突为例，哈马斯10月7日对以色列发动恐怖袭击，杀害至少1300人，无论什么原因都无法为这种行为辩解，而新加坡也在第一时间谴责这样的可怕攻击。李总理说，面对突袭的以色列有权自卫以消除对自己的危险，而从人性的角度来看，以色列遭受如此严重和可怕的攻击后，不可能不采取行动。但他指出，以色列行使自卫权时，必须遵守国际法，包括战争法和国际人道主义法，减少平民伤亡，解决人道主义问题。📸：海峡时报

Roman-era mosaic is uncovered during the excavation of an old building in Syria .

RASTAN, Syria —in 2022 Syria uncovered a large intact mosaic that dates back to the Roman era, describing it Wednesday as the most important archaeological discovery since the country's conflict began 11 years ago.

Journalists were shown the mosaic in the central town of Rastan near Homs, Syria's third largest city.

The mosaic, at 120 square meters (around 1,300 square feet), was found in an old building that Syria's General Directorate of Antiquities and Museums had been excavating.

Lebanese and Syrian businessmen from the neighboring country's Nabu Museum bought the property that dates back to the 4th century and donated it to the Syrian state.

Each panel was filled with square-shaped, small colorful stones measuring about half an inch on each side.

Dr. Humam Saad, the associate director of excavation and archaeological research at the directorate, said among the scenes the mosaic shows is a rare portrayal of Ancient Amazon warriors in Roman mythology.

"What is in front of us is a discovery that is rare on a global scale," Saad told The Associated Press, adding that the images are "rich in details," and includes scenes from the Trojan War between the Greeks and Trojans.

In Ancient Greek and Roman mythology, demigod hero Hercules slayed Hippolyta, queen of the Amazons, in one of his 12 labors.

Source : NPR website
📸 Omar Sanadiki

幸好平安回家了！一名泰国男子在以色列被哈马斯组织成员割喉，10月18日抵达泰国家中与家人团聚。

34 岁的泰国男子威塔瓦（Wittawat "Jack" Kunlawong）对媒体诉说生还过程。他说，他在距离加沙边境2公里处的一个养鸡场工作。当他正在工作时，哈马斯组织突袭并搜捕人员。他设法逃了出来，但不幸的是，他在逃离工作场所时遇到了一名哈马斯成员。他说：“他手中拿着一把刀，我试图去抢，而那人也试图反击；我被刺了数刀，最后我的喉咙被割破。他们还抢走了我身上所有的财物。”

威塔瓦说当时他失去了知觉，醒来时脖子上有一道严重的伤口。“我醒来后没看到任何袭击者，我想他们应该以为我死了，就把我扔在那里。”带着血淋淋的伤口，威塔瓦跑出现场求助。最后，他的朋友将他送往医院。在医院住了三天后，他才搭乘飞机返回泰国。威塔瓦的喉咙被严重割伤，登机后必须接受多项健康检查。

泰国皇家空军（RTAF）从以色列撤离了 136 名泰国人。威塔瓦 27 岁的妻子瓦萨娜（ Wassana Pimsuwan）和5岁的女儿在机场等他。他们紧紧拥抱在一起，喜极而泣。这是杰克四年前前往以色列后他们第一次见与家人团聚。瓦萨娜坚持不让丈夫再回以色列工作，他们计划一起在泰国从事农业工作。威塔瓦一直拥抱着女儿，不停地说他很高兴能回家。📸：泰国媒体Channel 3

➕Because my first born keeps asking why➕

🌻🌻🌻🌻

• REPOST from @sirianajanine “But why is a preschool teacher posting about Palestine? That’s so political.”

Kindly see yourself out, because you’re most likely a “progressive” person who doesn’t say this when I speak out against every other injustice that affects marginalized and oppressed peoples. 

The story of Palestine is the first injustice and struggle for liberation that I ever learned about. 🇵🇸 It’s what brought me to my work. 

In the past, Palestinians and their allies have been silenced and threatened for speaking out about the colonization of their land. 

In fact, until recently, people and governments would falsely call you antisemitic if you even said the name “Palestine”, and not “Palestinian territories.” This was intentionally meant to suppress solidarity and the truth about Palestine, while it also meant that antisemitism (a very present and dangerous form of bigotry against Jewish people) was misrepresented as criticizing Israel’s violent establishment and ethnic cleansing. 

And with so much false information and deflection that continues to frame Palestine as a “two-sided, complicated, religious conflict”, I had to speak out and share my lifetime of knowledge and research on the Palestinian struggle for justice. 

Please amplify Palestinian voices. Please listen to Jewish voices when they stand in solidarity and tell Israel to stop colonizing Palestine in the name of their religion. Israeli genocide does not represent Judaism. Justice for one is justice for all. 

I invite you to continue reading Palestinian stories and speaking with your children about Palestine, the way you do with all forms of racism and oppression. 

You are welcome to ask me questions to help you unlearn the anti-Palestinian and orientalist rhetoric we’ve all been taught. You are NOT welcome to attack me by falsely claiming my solidarity with Palestinians is antisemitic. 

There is hope. There is light. Freedom begins with knowledge. 

🌻🌻🌻🌻

What help is 20 truckloads of aid to #Gaza? nobody should fool anyone
Before the outbreak of conflict, an average of about 450 aid trucks were arriving daily to Gaza excluding commercial vehicles 
As for electricity Gaza Power Plant needs 450,000lt diesel per day to generate electricity at its operational capacity of 80MW 
Gaza had a total electricity generation capacity of around 220 MW and total need is 1 Million lt (100/150 oil trucks daily) excluding vehicles fuel oil consumption 
Additionally, daily min water need is 100 million liters. So this mill cannot turn with aid, the embargo must be lifted.

We're just over half way through the Ballinadee pumpkin patch and haunted bus and honestly we are so blown away by the response and the positive feedback from you all. To hear the sound of children running around laughing and playing, parents and adults mingling and enjoying themselves has made us want to make next year is even bigger and better.
With all that said the realisation of how lucky we are really hit. Seeing the recent flooding in East Cork and the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the middle east. Seeing so many homes and businesses destroyed around Cork and watching innocent families and children killed or affected by the conflict in Palenstine & Isreal has made us reflect on what if anything we can do.
The goal of this year's pumpkin patch was to raise funds towards feeding and sheltering our rescues over the winter. However, after taking it over amongst ourselves we have decided the majority of any profit we make this year we will share amoung charities aiding in the response to the floods in East Cork and toward humanitarian aid in the middle east. While this is only a very small thing we can do we would ask anyone who is able to donate anything they can afford to the links we will continue to share on our page and stories. We'd also askto try and support businesses in east Cork over the coming Christmas season to help rebuild.
Thanks

Ballots are in mailboxes! After six plus months of meetings, then events and forums, now canvassing and doorknocking, it’s election time. 

With endorsements from five former mayors, progressives and environmentalists, Aaron and Bob, business leaders and restaurant community, housing advocates and gun reform moms, grandmas I walk dogs with on the daily and the Sierra Club and Better Boulder…

…with a joy in learning and listening and communicating, with lifelong relationships in this hometown of mine, having served on many boards and active in many local issues, having founded and run a mission-driven, successful local company for 22 years, I am perhaps uniquely positioned to bring folks together just enough to push us out of a costly, frustrating status quo mired in conflict and onto a path toward real solutions.

There are many wonderful candidates to choose from. I’ve truly enjoyed getting to know my compatriots and getting to know this community I’ve so long cared for more deeply. It’s been an honor and (mostly) fun! 

Win or lose, I’m dedicated to being of service. Folks seem to think I’ll win—we’ll see. As I like to rejoinder when folks wish me luck, I don’t need luck—I need your vote! ✅

What is PEP Israel Palestine?

Progressive except Palestine (also known as PEP, alternatively written as progressive except for Palestine) is a phrase that refers to organizations or individuals who describe themselves politically as progressive, liberal, or left-wing but who do not express pro-Palestinian sentiment or do not comment on the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. Pro-Palestinian advocates regard PEP as a type of political hypocrisy and an example of anti-Palestinianism, while critics of the phrase regard it as anti-Israel and a smear against the pro-Israel left.

London's Metropolitan Police are reporting a significant surge in antisemitic and anti-Islamic hate crimes in the city since the start of the Israel-Hamas conflict. ⁠
⁠
In a statement Friday, they said that from October 1 to 18 the department saw 218 antisemitic offenses compared to 15 in the same period last year, while Islamophobic offenses jumped from 42 to 101, representing increases of 1,353 percent and 140 percent respectively. ⁠
⁠
The department said the crimes include abuse directed at individuals or groups in person or online, racially or religiously motivated criminal damage and other offenses. ⁠
⁠
They said the sharp rise has come despite an increased police presence near parochial schools, places of worship and communities where the "levels of concern" are known to be the highest. Police said officers have visited 445 schools and 1,930 places of worship, and plan to make more such visits. ⁠
⁠
The department reported 21 arrests for hate crimes during the period and encouraged people to report the offenses to the police. ⁠
⁠
Deputy Assistant Police Commissioner Ade Adelekan discussed the statistics with reporters Friday ahead of a pro-Palestinian march planned for Saturday in London. ⁠
⁠

At this morning’s Speak Out and Stand Up Against Hate event - I was honored to stand with such a diverse, powerful group of leaders who are bringing awareness to hate crimes in our community. Luna Banuri of the Utah Muslim Civic League said something that stuck with me.

"I stand here with the weight of my community’s vast range of emotions. And I am centering the most widely held belief amongst Muslims, that of standing with the oppressed and against evil or injustice. As a Hadith from the Prophet Muhammad said ‘Whoever among you sees evil, let him change it with his hand. And if he cannot do so, then let him change it with his tongue.’”

I couldn’t agree more.

Our great city is home to Muslims, Jews, and so many other beautiful communities. My heart is with all of you who are hurting and heartbroken.

Our goal this morning, and every single day, is to make this city as safe and welcoming to all people as we possibly can. To stand up and speak out against hate. I can’t solve the conflict or stop the pain, but I want Salt Lakers to know that I’ll always stand with you against evil and injustice.

Walking around the Florentine district of Tel Aviv on the morning of Shabbat, the Jewish day of rest, it would be very easy to forget that the country is at war. The coffee shops are filled with locals reading newspapers and meeting friends, as a steady stream of dog walkers pass by in the morning sunshine. It’s only when you stop to look that you see the posters showing faces of the people believed to currently be held hostage by Hamas in Gaza. Then, you notice the expressions of quiet sadness, two weeks to the day since the shock attack on Southern Israel. Is the mood due to what has been, or what now seems inevitable? While images of the horrific conditions inside Gaza fill the news feeds, the people of Israel know that any incursion will come at a high human cost for their own country too. With so many having friends and family in active service, the fallout will be personal.

Back at the Gaza border, the low hum of a distant drone circling above is regularly interrupted by the rush of a fighter, circling once, twice, before a plume of smoke appears in the distance. Seconds later, the boom of impact reaches the assembled media overlooking the scene. Time and again, the strikes hit all across the horizon, some falling into the no-man’s land in between our vantage point and the Gaza fence.

An unexpected crack and rush of rocket fire sends everyone to the ground, looking around, trying to work out the confusing order to the sounds they heard. An outgoing Israeli position has fired for the first time from very close nearby, leaving everyone a little more alert.

The sun sets over the horizon and the strikes continue. As the day fades and it becomes harder to focus, it dawns on me that there are no lights coming from Gaza. The skeletal shapes of the ruins which were so sad to see in the day have somehow taken on an even darker form.
.
.
.

A primary principle on the path of justice is to discern power dynamics.

In nearly every large conflict, there is a side that holds more power—money, allies, weapons, etc.—and another party that has relatively less.

In each instance, the side that holds more of this kind of power must act with discretion and reserve knowing that its power comes with responsibilities.

Those concerned about justice are always concerned about power. Who has it? Who doesn’t have it? Who must be protected and who must be restrained?

Hamas terrorists who carried out a surprise attack on October 7 were found to be under the influence of Captagon, a synthetic amphetamine-type stimulant that has been clandestinely produced in southern Europe and trafficked through Turkey to the consumer markets on the Arabian Peninsula, as reported by Nir Dvori of Channel 12.

The pills were recovered from the pockets of many terrorists who lost their lives on Israeli soil.This stimulant drug, also known as the "cocaine for the poor," allowed the terrorists to commit heinous acts with a sense of calmness and indifference. Simultaneously, it kept them highly alert for extended periods and suppressed their appetite.

Captagon: Used by ISIS
Captagon gained notoriety in 2015 when it was discovered to be used by ISIS fighters to suppress fear prior to carrying out terrorist operations. As the influence of terrorist organizations like ISIS diminished, Lebanon and Syria took the reins and began producing and distributing the drug on a large scale.Gaza, in particular, became a popular market for the drug, especially among addicted young individuals.

Captagon belongs to the amphetamine family and was initially developed to address attention disorders, narcolepsy, and depression. Despite its highly addictive nature and potential for inducing psychotic reactions, it continues to enjoy popularity in the Middle East due to its affordability and ease of manufacturing. In poorer countries, the drug can be purchased for a dollar or two, while in wealthier nations, it may cost up to 20 dollars per pill. Its primary effects include arousing feelings of euphoria, reducing the need for sleep, suppressing appetite, and providing sustained energy. 
According to medical professionals in Lebanon and Syria, Captagon is not only prevalent among fighters but is also frequently used by desperate civilians residing in conflict zones.Once a source of revenue for ISIS members through drug smuggling, Captagon has now become a major source of income for Syria and is actively supported by Hezbollah.

What are the Rules of War?⁣
⁣
The rules of war are an internationally recognised set of guidelines that outline what parties at war can and can’t do. These are meant to protect people who are not involved in the conflict. Without the rules of war, organisations like MSF would not be able to respond to the urgent medical needs of people trapped in conflict zones, and many lives would be lost unnecessarily.⁣
⁣
When parties at war break these rules, thousands of innocent lives are lost, and suffering is exacerbated. For organisations like MSF, becoming a target means that we are unable to provide care for people who need it the most. For us, there is no greater crime than this.

York University has issued a warning: if the institution’s student unions do not recant or sufficiently defend their collective statement on the Israel-Palestine conflict, they will risk losing their relationship with the university.

The university’s statement, released to the public on Friday, addressed the “serious and ongoing harms caused by [the groups’] statement,” which declares “solidarity with the Palestinian people” against “the settler-colonial apartheid state of Israel.”

“Since 1948, Palestinian people have been systemically displaced from their land and homes as a result of state-sanctioned violence, siege, and genocide,” reads the student unions’ statement in part. “Our Unions remain unwavering in our support of the Palestinian people's fight for self-determination and liberation.”

In its statement, York University said the unions must retract the statement, issue an apology, acknowledge the impact of the statement on campus, and remove all union executives by 5 p.m. on Oct. 25.

Alternatively, the university said the student unions can challenge the assertion that the statement breached York’s Regulation Regarding Student Organizations by the same deadline.

If it’s determined the statement did break the school’s anti-harassment policy, York said it could impose sanctions, the most severe of which would be cutting ties with the offending union.

“The University is deeply disappointed that this step is now required, but we are compelled to uphold University policies and to act in the best interests of the York community, including those of the student unions and their memberships,” said administrators for York in the statement.

The Jewish Campus Coalition previously condemned the statement from the student unions, calling the remarks “blatantly prejudiced” and demonstrating “an extreme and deliberate disregard for not only Jewish but all students affected by the horrible tragedies that have been and continue to occur.”

Neither the York Federation of Students, York University Graduate Student Association nor Glendon College Student Union have recanted the statement.

"We carry the weight of our planet's traumas, the wars, the violence, the injustice, and oppression. We also carry the weight of our own individual struggles and past traumas and wounds. But fear not, for each of us has a purpose on this world. Don't let their fear infiltrate your soul. Look at the grander scheme of things. Everything unfolds for a reason, even the darkest moments. The universe's essence is change, reshaping societies and our own lives. Change and conflict have their conclusions, and this is how the cosmos teaches right from wrong. Armed with this awareness, we can stand for what's just, mend the world's flaws, and empower the good. Don't let the media or bad news dim your inner light. What we need now more than ever is Oneness. Duality ain’t gonna take us anywhere.”

Chaos erupted in Berlin, leaving dozens of police officers injured, as pro-Palestinian protesters took to the streets of the German capital in defiance of the local ban on such demonstrations over concerns of antisemitism.

On Wednesday evening, protests were held throughout Germany following the explosion at a hospital in Gaza, which international media initially blamed on Israel without evidence. In the Berlin borough of Neukölln, hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists gathered despite the city’s ban on anti-Israel protests. The demonstration devolved into violence and rioting, with local police reporting that the demonstrators attacked officers with stones, bottles, and makeshift pyrotechnic missiles.The police also reported that several cars, a truck, and a tree were set on fire during the chaos. The police, in turn, used pepper spray on some of the violent rioters and used water cannons to put out garbage cans and tires that were set on fire in the streets.According to the Berlin Police, 174 people were arrested at the banned protest and 65 police officers were injured during the rioting that lasted until the early hours of Thursday morning. The protest was organised by the “Youth against Racism” activist group, German broadcaster NTV reports.According to the German tabloid newspaper Bild, protesters in Berlin chanted slogans such as “Free Palestine,” “Allahu Akbar,” and “Israel – child murderer”.

Pro-Palestinian protests were also held in other German cities, including in Frankfurt where police deployed water cannons against the banned demonstration, as well as in Hamburg and in Nuremberg.The protests came just hours after a Jewish synagogue was firebombed with Molotov cocktails in the early hours of Wednesday in Berlin.Jewish leaders in Germany have warned their communities to be cautious of potential antisemitic attacks amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas after the terror group launched a series of deadly terror attacks, leaving at least 1,400 Israelis and tourists dead, in addition to approximately 200 people taken hostage by the radical Islamist organisation.In response, Jewish communities in Germany have advised against speaking Hebrew

As 20 aid trucks arrived at a UN storage facility in central Gaza on Saturday, October 21, uncertainty loomed for the 2.3 million people still blockaded there.

It’s been two weeks since Hamas attacked Israel, killing close to 1,400 people in coordinated attacks that prompted devastating Israeli retaliation and increased tensions around the world. 

Israel said it would its increase strikes on Gaza, starting Saturday.

Hamas is holding as many as 200 hostages it kidnapped during the attacks, and says 50 more captives are being held by other armed groups inside Gaza.

Hamas previously said 20 hostages were killed by Israeli air strikes, without providing details.

Two American hostages were released by Hamas Friday and handed over to Israeli authorities after Qatar helped mediate their release. 

In addition to Israeli hostages, Hamas is also holding citizens of Thailand, Argentina, Britain, Germany, France and Portugal.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed ‘mighty vengeance’ for the Oct. 7 massacre. 

A ground invasion of Gaza by Israeli forces could come at any time.  More than 4300 Palestinian people, including women and children, have been killed in the retaliatory attacks.

Demonstrations around the world show deep divisions in communities supporting Palestinian and Israeli civilians.

The U.S. has affirmed support for Israel’s right to defend itself, but officials have expressed doubt that Israel has crafted an endgame to the conflict that threatens to draw in other countries and divide the world.

Arab leaders at a Cairo summit on Saturday condemned the Israeli bombardment of Gaza. With Israel and the U.S. absent from the summit, no agreement was made toward how to contain the violence.

Gulf Cooperation Council and ASEAN countries called for a durable ceasefire, the immediate release of civilian hostages and detainees, and a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

China’s special envoy on Middle East affairs has also called for efforts to implement a two-state solution and promote an early, comprehensive, just, and lasting settlement of the Palestinian question.
Protesters hold a demonstration in support of a ceasefire against the Palestinians in Gaza below Capitol Hill on Friday in Washington, DC.  #war #peace #conflict #protest #middleeast #foreignpolicy

Over 200 people rallied on the University of Utah campus Friday evening in support of Palestine in the latest war between Israel and Hamas, an armed Palestinian militant group.

“What has happened has been a result of 75 years of imprisonment, physical and emotional torture, humiliation, displacement, ethnic cleansing and genocide,” said Yafi, a U graduate student. “This was not unprovoked.” 

Hamas’ recent attack on Israel and Israel’s offensive in Gaza in response is an escalation in a long conflict that has already left thousands dead on both sides.

Some students who attended the rally have personal connections to the ongoing conflict in the Middle East.

Jack Bellows, a U student who’s the chair of the Democratic Socialists of America, has a grandfather who was born in the Palestinian city Ramallah, and his neighborhood was bombed in 1948. This was part of what Palestinians refer to as the “Nakba,” Arabic for “catastrophe” – when militia attacks that preceded the Arab-Israeli war led to the killing of approximately 15,000 Palestinians. 

In a press conference on Thursday, Gov. Spencer Cox said his heart was broken for Palestinians as well, but that he had zero empathy for Hamas. 

He added that any efforts to harm or threaten Jewish citizens or Israelis in Utah would be met with, “swift justice to the fullest extent of the law.” 

“I would say the exact same thing towards our Palestinians,” he said. “Our Palestinians, they are our neighbors. They are Utahns and we love them and we’re grateful they’re here. And we extend those same protections to you as well.”

One of the impacts of trauma is a feeling of self sabotage and not being able to move forward in life - feeling stuck, things grinding to a halt, constantly coming up against brick walls.
It’s incredibly frustrating. 😫

For all our best intentions, we simply can’t move past the blocks, can’t seem to achieve our goals.
Shame can arise as we compare our progress to others.
We can feel inadequate and really disappointed in ourselves.

We experience this inner conflict and turmoil. One part of us wants to achieve a goal which is polarised with another part of us who won’t allow this happen.

WHY?!! WHY wouldn’t we want to progress with our goals?

It’s a trauma response.
We identify this part of us who is causing the bottleneck. The first step is to know it’s there. We can assume this part is in a lot of FEAR.

All parts have positive intent for the system.

There’s usually a fear of losing something, or something bad happening.
For example, if we achieve our goal, perhaps people will be jealous and try to harm us. It can be traced back to childhood. When good things happened to us, there were negative consequences and severe punishment.

Perhaps as the scapegoat child it wasn’t safe to outshine the golden child. We learnt it was safer to squash our intelligence and not bring attention to ourselves. We HAD to take on this strategy to get our basic needs met as a minor.

Acknowledge the fears and let this part of you know - things are different now. We can handle jealousy, we can handle people not liking us, we can handle other people’s discomfort at us achieving our goals. We have WAY more resources, information and knowledge than we did all those years ago.

#selfcompassion #yougotthis

How did you learn to lace your shoes? 

In Subotica, our team covers several informal accommodations in order to provide people with basic necessities, such as food, water, and showers. In spending time with people during distributions, we get the chance to witness the living realities of people on the move: we share stories, we play games and we have different conversations.

During one of our distributions in a squat hosting around 200 people, we met A. A is a 12 years old boy from Syria who is currently on his way to Holland to meet with his uncle. Soon after we arrived at the squat, A. caught our attention. He was walking around with only one shoe and he had scratches all over his face and hands. He had just arrived in Serbia from Bulgaria with three other people- two of them also minors. The scratches, they explain, were caused by the bushes in which they were hiding in order not to be seen by the police and cross the border.

We accompanied him to the car where we gave him a pair of shoes. If in his behavior A. was acting as an adult, when we gave him the shoes, we realised he could not lace them. No one knew where his parents were and no one was there to take care of him or teach him how to tie a pair of shoes. 

As an accompanied minor, the story of A. holds many questions that we will not be able to answer. According to UNICEF, children represent one quarter of all refugees and migrants who came to Europe. There is a tendency in migration studies to rank migrants as victims of socio-political strucutres that force them to move. According to the stories we hear as NNK, the reasons why children migrate are complex and diverse. Like their adult counterparts, also minors should be considered as active agents of their lives. In war countries, families can seek the possibility to send their children abroad to give them a better future. They may flee due to war, conflict or other situations involving serious human rights violations. Compared to other groups, however, unaccompanied minors face higher risks of violence, exploitation, and abuse, including gender-based violence. 

🖊 @ginevra_canessa
📸 Benni

What is happening in Gaza is neither a conflict, nor a clash, nor a crisis. We should use the right terminology. 
What is happening #LandGrabbing, which is a large-scale acquisition of land through the purchase or lease of significant tracts by domestic and transnational companies, governments, and powerful individuals. Other methods of appropriating someone else’s space and territory include colonization, occupation, annexation, and war, each based on distinct yet complementary arrangements, where one can lay the groundwork and create conditions for the application of another.

Sources: 
Towards a better understanding of global land grabbing, 2011
Three Forms of Land Grabbing in Palestine, 2020

Oktober is de Maand van de Geschiedenis en daarom tippen we je graag deze fascinerende boeken om het verleden te ontdekken. ⁠
⁠
𝙃𝙞𝙩𝙡𝙚𝙧, 𝙎𝙩𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙣, 𝙑𝙖𝙙𝙚𝙧 𝙚𝙣 𝙢𝙤𝙚𝙙𝙚𝙧 van Daniel Finkelstein: In 𝙃𝙞𝙩𝙡𝙚𝙧, 𝙎𝙩𝙖𝙡𝙞𝙣, 𝙑𝙖𝙙𝙚𝙧 𝙚𝙣 𝙢𝙤𝙚𝙙𝙚𝙧 vertelt Finkelstein het ontroerende en soms huiveringwekkende verhaal van zijn ouders. Het is een verhaal over vervolging en overleven en over de bijna onvoorstelbare moed van twee gewone families.⁠
⁠
𝘿𝙚 𝘽𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙜𝙤𝙣𝙙𝙞ë𝙧𝙨 van Bart van Loo: Meesterverteller Bart van Loo neemt de lezer op sleeptouw langs duizend jaar Europese geschiedenis. Zijn zoektocht voert hem naar het ontstaan van de Nederlanden in de vijftiende eeuw. En wat blijkt? De Lage Landen zijn een Bourgondische uitvinding.⁠
⁠
𝘿𝙚 𝙝𝙤𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙧𝙙𝙟𝙖𝙧𝙞𝙜𝙚 𝙤𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙤𝙜 𝙩𝙚𝙜𝙚𝙣 𝙋𝙖𝙡𝙚𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙖 van Rashid Khalidi is geen verhaal van slachtofferschap, noch probeert het de fouten van Palestijnse leiders of de opkomst van nationalistische bewegingen aan beide kanten te ontkennen. Maar door de geschiedenis op een heldere manier in kaart te brengen vanuit Palestijns perspectief, geeft dit boek een nieuwe kijk op een conflict dat tot op heden voortduurt.⁠
⁠
𝙉𝙖 𝙙𝙚 𝙗𝙚𝙫𝙧𝙞𝙟𝙙𝙞𝙣𝙜 van Barbara Skarga is een urgent boek, nu een beter begrip van de complexe realiteit en verhouding van Rusland met zijn buurlanden meer dan ooit noodzakelijk is.⁠
⁠
𝙂𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙞𝙟𝙙 𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙡𝙞𝙚𝙯𝙚𝙣 van Jolande Withuis: In 𝙂𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙩𝙞𝙟𝙙 𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙡𝙞𝙚𝙯𝙚𝙣 schetst Withuis met een schat aan materiaal het leven, de liefdes (m/v), de vriendschappen en de lange, veelzijdige loopbaan van een van Nederlands meest gerenommeerde beeldend kunstenaressen. Het resultaat is een springlevend en aangrijpend portret van een begaafde, fascinerende en moedige vrouw.⁠
⁠
T/m 31 oktober lees je deze boeken als e-book voor €6,99 per stuk. Welk boek ga jij lezen in de Maand van de Geschiedenis?

The world is so very big,  and yet so very small as well. A few weeks ago I was grocery shopping at Trader Joe’s , and I noticed a man who looked very familiar  to me. As I did my rounds on two levels, it suddenly hit me why I recognized him. He was MARTIN  FLETCHER, the longtime NBC Middle East correspondent, who retired  just last year. As I finally reached the checkout line, I noticed FLETCHER a few persons ahead of me. After paying for my groceries I headed out  and I was able to quickly say to him, “ We miss you very much  on NBC !” He thanked me and continued on his way. 2 days ago I saw a very emotional FLETCHER speaking with STEPHANIE RUHLE about the conflict in Gaza and choking back tears saying that he had family members who were hostages. Yesterday his family’s prayers were answered when the first two American hostages freed were indeed MARTIN  FLETCHER’S relatives .

But (maybe) it ain’t that easy for your average OG.
The (in)famous original "American gangster”, Ellsworth Raymond “Bumpy” Johnson, who, according to his widow "had a hand in almost every illegal enterprise operating in Harlem" including the drug game which ravaged Harlem in the days before Hip Hop, was quoted in a 1967 interview as saying "what I really am, when the chips are down, is a Black nationalist". In between his notorious underworld dealings he is known to have offered "protection" to the legendary actor Paul Robeson who was then under siege from the ant-communist white forces of amerika. Johnson also offered protection to a New York Chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) when they were threatened by "local gangsters of the Mafia" while CORE was protesting brutality against blacks in front of a police station. Bumpy sent a message to the Mafia stating "If any of those CORE kids are harmed, I will not guarantee the safety of any Mafia member in Harlem." And in 1964, Johnson is also known to have offered to "take care of" Malcolm Xs "problems" after he came into conflict with the Nation of Islam (NOI). Malcolm X, who reportedly knew Johnson from back in the 1940s when X was a small time Harlem street hustler known as "Detroit Red" was quoted as saying to one of his trusted aids after walking away from Bumpy 
I don't want Black folks killing Black people
Even still, after Malcolm X was assassinated, it was Bumpy who, according to Karen E. Miller, the author of Harlem Godfather, 
Went around to all the businesses in Harlem and said 'open up your cash registers 'cause you have to make a donation,' and he took a little bit of something from everybody in order to pay for the funeral of Malcolm X

The Black Nationalist poet Amiri Baraka is quoted as saying that “Bumpy johnson was one of the first to insist that Black dudes run their own rackets and stop paying off the white boys,” but in 1968, Bumpy is quoted as having said to then Student Non-Violence Coordinating Committee (SNCC) leader H. Rap Brown after Brown gave a fiery speech in Harlem I agree with a lot of what you said.

The Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of the Awka Capital Territory Development Authority, Mr Ossy Onuko, whose security convoy allegedly assaulted a commercial driver has stated his side of the story.
Some videos trended on social media on Friday, showing a scene of altercations, between the ACTDA boss who was said to have ordered his officers and touts to beat up a driver of the G.U.O. Motors “just because he overtook his convoy”.
The videos, however, generated mixed reactions among residents of the state, who called on the governor, Prof. Chukwuma Soludo, to caution his appointees.
However, in his reaction, following the public outcry, the accused, Mr Onuko, said the situation was misinterpreted.
He stated this in a statement made available to journalists on Saturday, in which he said he was surprised with the rate at which the story was misinterpreted and fed half-baked to the public by the social media users who did not care to get his side.
Explaining what transpired, he said, “I have been inundated with calls and messages from well-meaning friends, colleagues and Ndi Anambra over a video clip that has gone viral on social media regarding an altercation between a GUO driver and myself, the Managing Director/Chief Executive Officer of Awka Capital Territory Development Authority.
I wish to state clearly the facts as they are, as I owe this to the public we graciously serve. Certainly, I cannot take their sensibility for granted.

Years ago, a grizzly bear bluff-charged EBS columnist Benjamin Alva Polley—the sow veered off about five yards away, avoiding conflict after Polley encountered her cub. ⁠
⁠
In this column, he describes the importance of carrying bear spray, understanding bear behavior, and taking any measure possible to avoid shooting a bear. The fall hunting season coincides with hyperphagia—a period when bears eat as many calories as possible to fatten up for winter hibernation—and human-bear conflict is more likely. ⁠
⁠
Many of these conflicts will not end well for the bear, according to the current issue of “Dispatches from the Wild.” But knowledge and awareness can help improve those outcomes. ⁠
⁠
Read the column at the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
📷️: Jim Peaco / NPS⁠

“If you're not careful, the newspapers will have you hating the people who are being oppressed, and loving the people who are doing the oppressing.” ― Malcolm X

Malcolm X's famous quote highlights the profound influence and potential bias of media outlets on public perception. It cautions that, without discernment, one can be subtly manipulated by skewed narratives or selective information. Essentially, instead of empowering the marginalized, the media might inadvertently paint them as adversaries, while portraying the oppressors in a sympathetic or favorable light.

Can you relate it to the Western media's bias regarding the recent Palestine-Israel conflict?

It's a call to be vigilant, question, and seek out diverse sources of information to gain a comprehensive understanding of issues. 📰 📺 🇵🇸

Against the Grey is a system-agnostic adventure about anthropomorphic animals taking up arms to defend their forest against the greed of the Grey.

The adventure is presented through two pamphlets, one for the referee and one for the players and now comes with a third pamphlet containing 6 pre-generated characters.

The Referee Pamphlet contains the main situation, the factions, a system to escalate the local conflict, and random tables for NPCs.

From Domestic Abuse to Post Separation Abuse: these are the #wordsfrommyabuser (submitted by OMB members)

Background: “Your problem is you’re not very smart and you attempt to be clever and subversive but you’re not intelligent enough.”

Through this campaign, it is our goal to educate family court professionals on the reality of post separation abuse. If you are a family court professional, we ask that you:

Imagine yourself in the shoes of a survivor.

Imagine believing you did the right thing in leaving an abusive relationship.

Imagine discovering a new, often more painful form of abuse: post separation abuse.

Imagine your child being used as a pawn for the sole purpose of hurting you.

Imagine being unable to protect your child and if you try, you are reprimanded and punished. Imagine being labeled as “high conflict” when you are simply desperate to protect your child. 
Imagine the system that you thought would protect you, failing you.
 
Imagine getting messages like this every day, the attacks are pervasive and unrelenting, affecting every part of your life: your job, your mental health, your cognitive functioning, your emotional state, and your ability to parent.
 
We don’t have to imagine; this is our life.
 
Signed, Victims of Post Separation Abuse
 
To learn more, go to www.postseparationabuse.com
 
If you would like to submit a quote for our campaign, please email it to postseparationabuse@gmail.com. For each quote we use, One Mom‘s Battle will make a $10 donation to our friends at the National Family Violence Law Center at the George Washington University.
 
#Postseparationabuse #FamilyCourt #DomesticViolence #CoerciveControl #InstitutionalBetrayal #DomesticViolence

Long before the rise of social media, British producer Bryn Jones dedicated his entire work as Muslimgauze to conflicts and history in the Muslim world, often with an emphasis on the Israeli–Palestinian case. Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon inspired Jones to research the conflict's origins; his research further grew to encompass other conflict-ridden, predominantly Muslim countries including Afghanistan, Pakistan, Chechnya, Iran and Iraq. 

He concluded that Western interests for natural resources and strategic-political gain were root causes for many of these conflicts and should Western meddling halt, said regions would stabilise.

Jones frequently netted criticism for never having visited the Middle East. He said in a 1994 interview, "I don't think you can visit an occupied land. It's the principle. Not until it's free again.”

Leaders and top officials from more than a dozen countries have gathered in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, for a conference Summit for Peace to discuss ways to de-escalate the Israel-Hamas war amid growing fears of a wider West Asia conflict.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi in his opening remarks invited leaders to come to an agreement for a road map to end the humanitarian disaster in the Gaza Strip and revive a path to peace between Israel and the Palestinians. 

He said, the roadmap’s goals included the delivery of aid to Gaza and agreeing to a ceasefire, followed by negotiations leading to a two-state solution.
	
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas used his opening remarks to say that Palestinians will not be forced off their land. The absence of any official from the Israeli side dampened expectations for what the summit could achieve.
	
The meeting also included officials from Jordan, Qatar, Italy, Spain, the EU and UK. But, key notable absentees include Israel, the US and Iran.

Different groups formed a 'human chain' along Roxas Boulevard on October 18, to protest the ongoing reclamation projects in the country.

Two months after President Marcos Jr. verbally announced the suspension of reclamation projects along Manila bay, land filling and construction continues, advocates stressed.

Environmental defenders should continue to enjoin the fisherfolk communities to defend Manila bay despite the threats, anti-reclamation activists Jhed Tamano and Jonila Castro said. 

Tamano and Castro went missing for 17 days.

"We see patients arriving in worse and worse conditions," says Gina, Medical Coordinator in Khartoum. Due to the conflict, travel is difficult and dangerous, and people postpone moving until the last minute to avoid the roads. 

Even at the Salam Centre for Cardiac Surgery, patients are arriving in fatal conditions: among them, a little girl from Geneina, on the border with Chad.

I don’t know why my “dream man” doesn’t show up in my life… 😢

That’s something a friend of mine recently mentioned during one of our catch-ups. Super interesting… I was very curious into which direction her stories and way of perceiving the world would go. It went down a totally different path than expected, which then made me assume this topic isn’t a priority at the moment.

Two hours later, after having an incredible breakfast and philosophizing about authenticity and the best way to explore when traveling across Asia, we ended up at the topic of freedom, and what it means. And then she casually dropped the sentence “yeah, I love my current freedom and flexibility SO much. I don’t want anybody to limit it. I’m not sure if I’m ready for somebody by my side.”

There it was! I asked my friend if I’m allowed to reflect something back that I saw, and she agreed. So, I asked her: 

“Do I understand correctly: you think that being in a relationship would limit your freedom? While at the same time a part of you wants your dream man to show up in your life?”

“Ha!” she answered & started thinking…. and we went into a deeper conversation about this topic. To cut a long story short: 

We realized one of her worries was that with a man by her side, she wouldn’t be able to act as spontaneously and be as adventurous as she is right now.

I asked her if that assumption was really true, in the sense of an ultimate truth. Nope, it was a fear. My friend then allowed me to offer a more empowering perspective:

 “What if the king by your side wants to explore life WITH YOU? And in cases he doesn’t want to, he is more than happy for you to explore on your own, or with other friends? OR: Maybe he has adventure plans in mind you cannot even imagine in your wildest dreams… How does that sound to you?”

The smile on my friend’s face was priceless. She smiled like a five year old on the birthday party, who was just gifted with a strawberry cake and was told that her party would end with a “kids disco”.

Over to you: Is a subconscious conflict in your life keeping you away from experiencing abundance?

#inspiration #mindfulness #thoughtleadership #personaldevelopment #balilife

Laila, a teacher by profession, pushing for peace in Mali – read and get inspired 👇🏿 
Laila is President of the Women's Leaders Association of Macina and her commitment to speaking up for women in her community started with the marginalisation of little girls from their right to education. Laila and her colleagues work in partnership with the municipality and the administrative authorities to organise community dialogues for the peaceful settlement of disputes. 
In this work, women are the key to peace: 
“In any case, I think that women have a major role to play in peacebuilding. Because peace begins in the family, then in the village and then in the whole community. Women remain the pillars of our families (…) I think every woman should be aware of the role she can play in strengthening social cohesion and peaceful coexistence in our country.” 
 Residing in Mali, a country badly affected by conflict for years, the dream is peace: “Yes, I dream of lasting peace for my country. I dream of seeing a frank dialogue for peace in our commune and further between the sons and daughters lost to armed groups and decision-makers at all levels in Mali. 
I dream of seeing an in-depth analysis of the conflicts for a lasting resolution of the grievances that pit us against each other. I dream that our country, Mali, will once again become a haven of peace and peaceful coexistence.” 
 For the annual UN Security Council Open Debate on Women, Peace and Security, together with many other organisations, Oxfam is calling for the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation and leadership of women in all crises and conflicts and urge the Security Council, the UN, and Member States to uphold them. 
#NoWomanNoPeace #WomenPeaceAndSecurity

Apologizing is no easy task and I absolutely love how THE TIME MACHINE skillfully follows one girl’s journey to courageously take responsibility for her mistake and set things right with her friend.
 
After offending her best friend Nia, Bailey wants to apologize, but finds it difficult to express her remorse. She sets upon building a time machine to go back and undo her mistake. When she struggles to finish the project, Nia unexpectantly aids in the completion of the time machine.  Together, they both venture into the contraption, enabling Bailey to deliver a heartfelt apology. This pivotal moment allows the two friends to mend their relationship and move forward.
 
I especially appreciate the “Apologizing Do’s and Don’ts” included in the back to help guide readers when making their own amends.

Peace begins within. 

We are so quick to look outside of ourselves, our own thoughts, feelings, actions and inherited beliefs. 

We are so quick to look for solutions, for “what to do and say” — this is a distraction from the real, hard work of addressing the war, violence, hatred and rage that live within our minds and bodies. 

Start with yourself. If the goal is peace — how can you make peace with yourself, first? How can you make peace with your friends, loved ones and community? 

Peace is a verb. 

Are you engaging in conflict in the name of peace? This in itself is a contradiction — this is the problem’s very root. 

Until we can embody what we wish to see in the world, we will not be able to actualize it.

Healing begins within. Dismantling begins within. 

Ask Yourself:
• What messages of hate have I inherited? 
• What wars have I inherited? 
• What rage lives within me? 
• Towards who? 
• How am I violent in my own life and who am I violent towards in words, thoughts or deeds? 
• Do I wish death on anyone?
• Where does that feeling come from?
• What would need to happen for me to make peace with all my relations and community?

The person whose advice I will follow is someone in true integrity - who can own and identify the roots of their own violence, who do not bypass themselves, and instead, integrate this awareness into an active practice of becoming love. 

Can you love your enemy?

It begins with loving the rejected parts of yourself. 

Once you recognize that all judgment is self-judgement, you can see where your work begins.

This is the hardest thing to do because we want to be “right” and we want to fight a perceived enemy —  these are the human qualities preyed on most by those invested in separation, war and division as a tool for making profit. 

Resistance — true resistance — begins within. It begins with knowing your own mind and your own values, first. 

Resist the urge to allow hate into your heart. Resist the violent thoughts about others — your siblings in one global family. Resist becoming what you criticize. Free yourself, and you will see — love is the most effective solution. 

PS. I love you.

📸 by @theintuiter

In an interview with the Kaimin, University of Montana President Seth Bodnar said his goal for UM is for it to serve as “an engine for social mobility” and to create an “educated citizenry.” But if the University hopes to encourage civic engagement, it needs to fight against the Legislature’s hostility towards student voting rights, not submit to its whims in the name of avoiding conflict.

This year, the University decided not to even forward the renewal of MontPIRG’s optional fee to the Board of Regents, the governing body for the Montana University System, because the administration thought it wouldn’t get approved and would take attention away from UM’s other funding needs, according to Kaimin reporting. Students approved of the effort to renew the fee with 82% ‘yes’ votes in last semester’s student government election. 

The University’s decision betrayed the student body’s wishes and undermined MontPIRG’s get-out-the-vote and ballot-collection efforts on campus that have proven to be effective in getting more students involved in elections.

At the beginning of the semester, the Kaimin called on Bodnar and the University administration to back up its encouragement of civil discourse at UM with action. Yet UM robbed the student advocates at MontPIRG’s opportunity to lobby for the group’s fee and deprived the group of funding for promoting one of the main ways students participate: voting
The Kaimin asks that you remember all the laws the Legislature has moved forward from the past three years when election season comes around. Do your research to find out who made it harder for you to participate in the political process with their bills and votes. Stay up to date with when and how you can register to vote, because as we saw in 2022, the rules can change just weeks before election day.

Advocate for your own vote, students, since the University has shown it won’t stick up for you.

Editorial by Emily Tachetter @Emily_Tschetter

#MTPol #UMNews #VotingRights

It’s Domestic Violence Awareness Month and students had an honest, difficult, and brave conversation about the relationship conflict cycle that is present in many DV patterns. 

Healthy relationships have conflict. But they don’t tend to cycle over and over again through explosive bad behaviors that lead to the need for dramatic apologies. In the “calm” moments of DV relationships, more bonding is taking place, so that the next time tension starts to build we are even less likely to leave. 

It’s complicated, it’s personal, and, it’s predictable and widespread. All at the same time. Anyone can find themself in a relationship with an emotionally controlling person, anyone can get caught up. At the same time, some people are more at risk than others. 

It’s one of the most important conversations we can have in our communities. I remember what it took to set new standards for my own life—a LOT of support. We have to take care of each other. This is not separate from anything else happening today—DV numbers go up in conflict zones and when communities are under stress. 

Do you see this cycle in relationships around you? It’s not always clear that there’s one abusive partner and one victim, but the effects of unhealthy patterns are hard to hide. Please don’t ignore them if you see them.

I CONTRIBUTE TO PEACE WHEN... 🕊️💘🕊️2018 roadtrippade jag och min man i Kalifornien och i San José besökte vi The Rosicrucian museum.  Där hittade jag en mycket fin ”Declaration” som jag läser ibland och tänkte att jag låter dig ta del av den också. Den är mig så sant klingande och mjukt vägledande:

Contribution to Peace
 
* I contribute to Peace when I strive to express the best of myself in my contacts with others. 
* I contribute to Peace when I use my intelligence and my abilities to serve the Good. 
* I contribute to Peace when I feel compassion toward all those who suffer. 
* I contribute to Peace when I look upon all men and women as my brothers and sisters, regardless of race, culture, or religion. 
* I contribute to Peace when I rejoice over the happiness of others and pray for their well-being. 
* I contribute to Peace when I listen with tolerance to opinions that differ from mine or even oppose them. 
* I contribute to Peace when I resort to dialogue rather than to force to settle any conflict. 
* I contribute to Peace when I respect Nature and preserve it for generations to come. 
* I contribute to Peace when I do not seek to impose my conception of God upon others. 
* I contribute to Peace when I make Peace the foundation of my ideals and philosophy.

Apeirogon: A Novel
By Colum McCann

Based on the real-life experiences of Bassam Aramin, a Palestinian, and Rami Elhanan, an Israeli, two men bound by the violent deaths of their daughters, the novel is unlike anything the Irish-born writer has ever attempted.

From the National Book Award–winning and bestselling author of Let the Great World Spin comes an epic novel rooted in the unlikely real-life friendship between two fathers.
 
Bassam Aramin is Palestinian. Rami Elhanan is Israeli. They inhabit a world of conflict that colors every aspect of their lives, from the roads they are allowed to drive on to the schools their children attend to the checkpoints, both physical and emotional, they must negotiate.
 
But their lives, however circumscribed, are upended one after the other: first, Rami’s thirteen-year-old daughter, Smadar, becomes the victim of suicide bombers; a decade later, Bassam’s ten-year-old daughter, Abir, is killed by a rubber bullet. Rami and Bassam had been raised to hate one another. And yet, when they learn of each other’s stories, they recognize the loss that connects them. Together they attempt to use their grief as a weapon for peace—and with their one small act, start to permeate what has for generations seemed an impermeable conflict.
 
This extraordinary novel is the fruit of a seed planted when the novelist Colum McCann met the real Bassam and Rami on a trip with the non-profit organization Narrative 4. McCann was moved by their willingness to share their stories with the world, by their hope that if they could see themselves in one another, perhaps others could too.
 
With their blessing, and unprecedented access to their families, lives, and personal recollections, McCann began to craft Apeirogon, which uses their real-life stories to begin another—one that crosses centuries and continents, stitching together time, art, history, nature, and politics in a tale both heartbreaking and hopeful. The result is an ambitious novel, crafted out of a universe of fictional and nonfictional material, with these fathers’ moving story at its heart.

Writer: Sam Leslie @samleslie_2024 Media: Sofia Gevorgian @sofia_gevorgian In 1688, the French challenged Dutch dominance at Little Komenda by constructing a trading post. The Eguafo Kingdom gladly received French interest as it capitalized off of competing trade partners. In pursuit of complete dominance, the Dutch malevolently turned their hostilities against the Eguafo Kingdom. The Dutch partnered with the neighboring African Adom state to attack the Eguafo; however, in early 1688, the Eguafo used French gold to bribe the Adom towards a neutral position. This tactic displayed the power of mutually beneficial international exchanges, the power of cooperation. Still, the Dutch refused to accept the plausibility of international communion; they allied instead with the Twifos, powerful local traders who were being “hindered to trade.” The ingrained power of the Dutch and Twifo usurped Eguafo control, and this led to Dutch victory and a beheaded king. Thereafter, the Dutch and the Twifo held influence over Little Komenda while French and English companies abandoned their factories. Clearly, there was a conflict between which pathways should pave the future of international relations: a pathway of exploitation or one of cooperation. In this battle the Dutch’s decision to choose exploitation over cooperation set a grim precedent. President His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan attended the Cairo Peace Summit, inaugurated today by Abdel Fattah El-Sisi, President of the Arab Republic of Egypt. The event drew the participation of leaders from various Arab nations and other countries, along with their governmental representatives, and the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres.

His Highness' participation in the summit aligns with the UAE’s continued efforts to collaborate with international partners in supporting all diplomatic endeavours and initiatives aimed at establishing a just, comprehensive, secure, and sustainable peace that ends violence in the region and enhances regional security and stability.

The summit, convened at the invitation of the Egyptian President, seeks to address de-escalation in the Gaza Strip and the Palestinian territories, emphasising the utmost priority of an immediate ceasefire and ending hostilities to prevent further expansion of the conflict and the exacerbation of humanitarian crises in the Middle East. Additionally, the summit will discuss developments related to the Palestinian cause, its future, and work towards defining a clear horizon to achieve a just, comprehensive, secure, and sustainable peace in the region.

But the billionaire seems to have a grand plan for X, which involves taking the free out of free speech. It couldn't have come at a more difficult moment.

This week, Musk's social-media company started to test a new $1 annual subscription feature called Not A Bot for new users creating an account in New Zealand and the Philippines. It's part of an effort to reduce spam and manipulation, the company said.

This week also happens to have been one of the worst for X's reputation since Musk's takeover of the company formerly known as Twitter, as the raging Israel-Gaza conflict has triggered the spread of alarming amounts of disinformation, lies, and inaccuracies.

Musk has flirted with the idea of putting the entirety of X behind a paywall for some time. His rationale for doing so has typically revolved around the idea that a paywall could go a long way towards removing the spam bots that clog up the platform with falsehoods.

There may be some merit to that. A paywall, for instance, may have stopped a fake account posing as an Al Jazeera journalist from cropping up and spreading unfounded claims about the Israel-Gaza conflict.

But by starting to charge users for access to X, Musk enters dangerous territory: a platform vital for documenting and sharing current affairs through free speech in real-time risks turning into a pay-to-play game.

If it isn't clear why that's bad, take a moment to reflect on the severity — and sources — of the information war that has gripped Musk's platform since the onset of Hamas' terrorist attacks on Israel on October 7.

Blame does not fall solely on bots for the spread of disinformation, faked images, and malicious misrepresentation of events about the Israel-Gaza conflict. Users exercising their version of free speech have been found culpable, too.

A post that recently circulated on X included a video described as footage of Hamas firing rockets from the Gaza Strip towards Israel.Reuters reported, however, that matching footage circulated in 2020 with Syria tagged as the location. The news agency added that the video did not depict the October 2023 conflict between Israel and Hamas.

✨Book Review✨
The Crown of Gilded Bones-
[#3 in Blood and Ash Series]
By Jennifer L Armentrout
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

I’m fully hooked, there’s no turning back. I had every intention of breaking the books up and continuing with my October TBR, but I just don’t have the desire to pick anything else up until I know what happens in this series.  I’ve heard from a few that this book feels like “filler”, but I disagree, I think it was important to finally see a relationship officially develop between Poppy and Cas as well as set the stage for the impending conflict between Atlantia and the Blood Crown. There was plenty of revelations, twists, and romance to keep me intrigued ( if you read this book, you know this word appears frequently 🙄). I really wish that the “I have a question” dialogue would decrease in the next book, but I feel that is how we discover some of the world building, so I try to not let it annoy me too much. 

Did anyone move to “A Shadow in the Ember” after reading this or go straight to book four, The War of Two Queens?

Do you know we are living in a post-truth era? 

Post-truth is a term coined in the Oxford dictionary in which people “respond more to feelings and beliefs than to facts.” This 21st-century phenomenon is present in the ongoing Israel-Hamas war, where misinformation and disinformation are shaping the narratives over social media. 

It's a clear reminder of the vitality of verifying information and seeking the truth amidst the chaos of the digital age. Learn more about this post-truth era and the historical context behind the conflict by reading more using the stories link in our bio.

“On June 2, the U.S. Department of the Interior blocked oil and gas leasing for the next twenty years within a ten-mile radius of Chaco Canyon — the site of a Puebloan civilization in now-northern New Mexico dating back over a millennium. Despite some support from people within the Pueblo tribes and Navajo Nation which surround the land, the vast majority of Navajo leaders have opposed these drilling restrictions. It’s essential that climate advocates hear them out.

Between high-profile cases of extractive industries seizing and polluting Indigenous land and the fact that climate change exacerbates the many environmental and economic challenges facing Indigenous communities, the climate movement routinely finds common ground with Indigenous people. But recently, the two groups have found themselves at odds. The Yurok tribe recently succeeded in an effort to have four hydroelectric dams removed from the Klamath River in Northern California, where renewable energy production was disrupting salmon runs. A majority of Alaska Native communities supported the now-approved Willow drilling project in Alaska despite the project’s significant carbon emissions, harm to wildlife, and a viral TikTok movement that spurred a #StopWillow petition with 5.1 million signatures. This conflict over Chaco Canyon drilling could drive yet another wedge between climate zealots and Indigenous people.

Collaboration with these tribes is vital to the climate movement — Indigenous communities have centuries of knowledge regarding environmental stewardship, and often view nature as sacred. Their leadership can help ensure the most sensible and effective climate solutions get implemented. If climate advocates want Indigenous support, we have to listen, build trust, and support their goals too.”

Check out the rest of my piece on the Chaco Canyon drilling discourse at RealClearEnergy!

We have an old Persian idiom that goes like this: they ask the fox who is your witness he responded my own tail. When the Gaza hospital parking tragedy took place a few days ago, a group of us immediately thought about how the truth might be soon discovered through the work of the Forensic Architecture and/or my dear friend Lawrence Abu Hamdan. Then came the biased and opinionated letter of the art world against Israel, unfortunately, signed by both Eyal Wiseman the dir ctor of AF and Lawrence. Today came the news that Forensic Architecture has done a preliminary investigation, casting significant doubt on Israel’s version of what happened at the Chrisitan hospital. Unfortunately, by signing that letter, both AF and Lawrence have damaged their objective credibity in shedding light on the truth about the incident. Of course, people who have already made up their mind about Israel, and what happened at the hospital would cheer this report, but for those who don’t, this report does little to change their mind. would’ve been better if Eyalmand Lawrence had stayed out of making a Partisan decision about the war via the letter to actually be able to have a more productive intervention in matters much more crucial than the right and wrong of the conflict on a moral and political level? Also calling the Israeli army IOF itself further reduces the credibility of the AF report. Last time I checked IOF stood for the International Osteoporosis Foundation.

🇵🇸 ¡ARTISTAS CONTRA EL APARTHEID! 🇵🇸

 Como artistas y productores culturales, nuestro trabajo tiene el poder de influir en la opinión pública. Hoy, cuando los medios de comunicación libran una guerra contra la verdad y despojan a este conflicto de su contexto histórico, tenemos la responsabilidad única de utilizar nuestra voz y nuestras prácticas artísticas para decir ¡NO MÁS! Ahora es el momento de protestar contra el apartheid y amplificar la justa causa del pueblo palestino y su resistencia contra 75 años de ocupación.

Read our editor-in-chief’s response to personal attacks made by an officer of @mesaiupui during a meeting of the @iupuiusg in regards to a recent article covering protests in downtown Indianapolis.

“We would like reconciliation with the officers and members of MESA, but not at the expense of truth, especially not in response to attempts to embarrass and malign us in public settings. That goes for any group that tries to sway our coverage, whether that be through financial incentive or popular pressure campaigns against our staff. 

We are all just students, trying to get our degrees and better ourselves. We can afford to be respectful of each other.

Lastly, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is something I have studied for a long time. The longer I study it, the more I am convinced that my opinion is like carrying water to the sea. There is nothing I could say that has not already been said by people with far more education and knowledge than me. 

That is why the only public stances I have taken on the matter have not explicitly supported either side. I support peace, I want innocent people to be protected, and I want conflict de-escalated. 

I do not think praising, justifying, or “providing nuance” to the actions of t*rrorists does any of those things, and I hope that my fellow students, MESA officers, USG senators, and members of the Indianapolis community can understand and respect this perspective and the continued independence of The Collegiate Commons.”

-@jstewart1517

Those of you who know me or have followed me for a while know that social justice is integral to the work that I put out into the world and also who I am as a person. What’s happening in the world at the moment is absolutely devastating and the loss of life is also devastating. I feel like often there is a tendency to look like you HAVE to have an opinion on social media however equally I can’t show up in this space being my authentic self, as someone who is abhorrently against injustice without speaking out. 

In Feb 2022 amnesty international released a report detailing the system of apartheid being enacted against the Palestinian people by the Israeli government, something which has largely been ignored by western media and a lot of us in the west have been ignorant to. I only found out about the report a few months ago because I decided to take a short course on human rights. Palestinian people have slowly had their rights to movement, basic needs like water and citizenship stripped away. Something that has been happening way before a few weeks ago. 

I can’t come on this platform and be authentic without acknowledging this injustice yet also acknowledging that there are Jewish victims of this conflict and that the reality of war is that those who have the least power are the ones most affected. This post isn’t to demean or undermine or pick sides. But it’s to stand up against the language that our own government is using and I see being repeated across social platforms. Standing up for the rights of Palestinian people doesn’t equate to being anti-Semitic or pro-Hamas. You can acknowledge the actions of an individual group doesn’t equate to the actions of the entire Palestinian population and similarly the actions of the Israeli state doesn’t equate to the actions of the Jewish population . 

The people need to be protected and the rights of every individual needs to be taken into account and it requires us as individuals disavowing the actions of both the Israeli state and the actions of Hamas whilst acknowledging that there has been ongoing violations of injustice being thwart on the Palestinian people for some time and this can’t be ignored anymore.
