The heavy security atmosphere on Ocotber 20 can be related to a wave of crackdown against the Sunni community, particularly dissident Sunni clerics and their close circles, including arrests and travel bans, especially since the Israel-Hamas conflict began earlier in the month.

HaalVsh, a website dedicated to human rights and events in Sistan-Baluchestan, reported violent arrests and mass detention of people around the Makki Mosque. “Security and military forces have surrounded the mosque and are attempting to enter,” it said.

Citing local sources, HaalVsh said security forces are transferring detained people with military as well as personal vehicles, while some of these people have been injured during the clashes with the forces.

In the footage from the protests, gunshots are heard, and security forces use teargas to control the crowd. In one of the videos, a group of regime forces, military vehicles and motorbikes are seen moving in a street as protesters surround them from both ends of the street.Iranian security forces attacked people in the Sunni-majority city of Zahedan in the southeast, and arrested many who wanted to hold rallies after Friday prayers.

Since Friday morning, security was tense around the Makki Jameh Mosque of Zahedan, where outspoken Sunni leader Mowlavi Abdolhamid weekly delivers fiery sermons criticizing the Islamic Republic and its policies. The people of the Sistan-Baluchestan, with Zahedan as provincial capital, have been holding weekly protests after security forces opened fire at peaceful protesters, killing nearly 100 on September 30, 2022, a day known as the Bloody Friday of Zahedan.

Abdolhamid has repeatedly called for an end to repression in the past one year and respect for civic and human rights in Iran.In another video, people are heard chanting “Not Gaza, Not Lebanon, I will die for Iran,” a common slogan in rallies against the Islamic Republic, which is the main sponsor of regional Islamist militias such as Hamas, which instigated the bloody war in the Middle East earlier in October.

During the Friday prayer sermons, Mowlavi Abdolhamid, who rejected the regime’s goal of destroying Israel the previous Friday, reiterat

Where the sky is painted with some dark clouds, a radiant rainbow shines through. We find ourselves contemplating the heart-wrenching events unfolding in Israel and Gaza. It’s a stark reminder of the fragility of peace and the resilience of humanity.

As we witness the turmoil and pain suffered by those directly affected, it’s essential to take a moment and reflect. We hold close the ones who bear the weight of this conflict in their hearts, for they are our friends, our family, and our fellow human beings.

In these troubling times, we are reminded of the privileges we often take for granted – the privilege to go to work, to attend school, to share meals with loved ones, to socialize with friends, to enjoy movies and concerts. It is a stark contrast to the lives disrupted by conflict.

Let us not forget the power of empathy and the strength of unity. While we may not have all the answers, we can stand together in support, offering our thoughts, prayers, and efforts toward a more peaceful world.

May this moment be a catalyst for gratitude and action, as we extend our hearts to those in need and work towards a world where everyone can enjoy these simple privileges without fear. 🕊️🇮🇱 

#ReflectAndUnite #PeaceForIsraelAndGaza

As I go on and live my normal life, which indicates how privileged one is to have a normal life in the first place, my heart keeps going back to Palestine and Israel. The agony of war is deeply painful.  We belong to the same world, and as a global citizen living a thousand miles away, I’m swamped with feelings of hopelessness and despair. Homes are wrecked, lives have been lost and children become orphans. 💔

As we go with our routine, faced with the stark realization that children and families affected by this conflict may never see their loved ones again, it is pertinent that we end this carnage and raise our voices for peace. ☮️

When will we realize the futility of killing and the brutality of it all? 

😥💔 ☮️

Calls for peace are growing louder amid intensifying demands for further action from the White House. Inside the U.S. Capitol building this week, rabbis were among those arrested as a group took over the rotunda, demanding the U.S. broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas. In New York, there was a massive gathering calling for Hamas’ release of all hostages. "They dragged 200 innocent Israelis into the hell of Hamas captivity, so that their crime against humanity could continue every day," said Elan Carr, CEO of the Israel American Council. 
Meanwhile in Illinois, Palestinian Americans grew angry at a vigil for a Palestinian American boy killed in what police say was a hate crime. As protesters demand more aggressive action from the White House, administration officials are urging calm. A recent explosion at a Gaza hospital was initially blamed on Israel, which later blamed the group Palestine Islamic Jihad — illustrating the need, they say, for calm in the fog of war. "I think this is a cautionary note for governments in the region, frankly, for press in responding to each and every twist and turn in this conflict. And there'll be more of these to come. It is important that people do not react immediately, or overreact immediately to first reports in a time of war," said Jon Finer, the principal deputy national security adviser.Still, competing narratives of the conflict are even causing legal sparring. Starbucks and a union representing its workers are suing each other over the union’s social media posts in support of Palestinians. Union leaders say it was put up without authorization and are suing Starbucks for defamation – for suggesting they support terrorism, they say. It's an acrimonious face-off in the midst of overwhelming calls for peace.

LONDON - Next month's MTV Europe Music Awards in Paris have been cancelled, organisers said on Thursday, citing "the volatility of world events" amid the ongoing conflict in Israel and Gaza.

The awards ceremony, scheduled to be broadcast live and at which the likes of Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo, Bad Bunny and the Foo Fighters were among nominees, was due to be held on Nov. 5 at Paris Nord Villepinte.

"Given the volatility of world events, we have decided not to move forward with the 2023 MTV EMAs out of an abundance of caution for the thousands of employees, crew members, artists, fans, and partners who travel from all corners of the world to bring the show to life," a spokesperson said in a statement.

Starbucks and the union representing its workers, Workers United, entered into a legal dispute on Wednesday. This disagreement arose following a social media post related to the Israel-Hamas conflict. In response, Starbucks filed a lawsuit against Workers United in a federal court in Iowa. 

The company alleges that a pro-Palestinian message posted from a union account during the early stages of the Israel-Hamas conflict caused frustration among hundreds of customers and negatively impacted Starbucks' reputation.

“Starbucks unequivocally condemns acts of hate, terrorism and violence,” said Starbucks Executive Vice President Sara Kelly. This is not helping the rumors that led Starbucks to claim in 2014 that "Rumors that Starbucks or Howard provides financial support to the Israeli government and/or the Israeli Army are unequivocally false."

CHRISTMAS IN COCONUT CREEK by @karissakinwordwrites: a spoiler-free review!🌴
RATING: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

Another brief detour from fall recs BECAUSE!

KARISSA KINWORD. YOU’VE DONE IT AGAIN.

I loved, LOVED, Forget Me Not so very much. I knew everything Karissa wrote would be an auto-buy for me, and this STILL blew me out of the water!

This cozy little Christmas rom-com hits every sweet spot we’re looking for in its genre, and it also does so much more. Imagine a hallmark Christmas movie, but make it more heartfelt, with unending witty and hilarious banter, some incredibly heartwarming friendships, beautiful character backstories, and a walloping dollop of SPICE🌶️💋

This book starts off running. The initial meet cute is completely hilarious, and Ophelia & Frankie’s chemistry is both filled to the brim with tension & also somehow feels so natural. Everything from here had me squirming & squealing, laughing & swooning. I love Ophelia and Frankie even separate from each other. Ophelia is charming & kind but also fiesty & unwilling to take any shit. Her friendship with Natalia is so sweet, fun and unconditionally supportive. Frankie & Mateo also have the most heartwarming relationship, and gives us the perfect scene to get to know our quiet and reserved MMC who becomes absolutely feral behind closed doors 👀

All of this wraps up with the sweetest and most hard-won HEA. We have no silly miscommunication, no unnecessary conflict, just two people who love each other overcoming natural obstacles in order to be together. I loved every hilarious, steamy, holiday bedecked & charming minute. Christmas in Coconut Creek releases on 10/24 and will be available on KU!

Thank you endlessly to @karissakinwordwrites for this early copy 🥹

QOTD: what are your favorite book character friendships? 🌴

The Value of Each Other

As much as the world around us tries to lure us into self-dependency, God created us for each other. For community. For a life that’s not alone.

The author of Proverbs said it like this:

“A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for a time of adversity.”
Proverbs‬ ‭17:17‬ ‭NIV

We’ll all face hard times—sometimes when we least expect it. But a friend’s genuine care can mean the world, a sibling’s unconditional love can’t be replaced, and a neighbor’s practical help is priceless. 

We need each other more than we realize: emotionally, practically, and spiritually.

If you’ve found yourself in a busy season where you’ve unintentionally neglected your true friends or been too busy for your real family, now is the time to reprioritize.

If there’s unresolved conflict with a friend or family member, and it’s slowly deteriorating the relationship, now is the time to set aside your pride and choose to make things right.

If you’re silently struggling alone, now is the moment to let someone in. Give them a call, send them a text, or show up on their doorstep. If you can’t be honest and vulnerable, it will be difficult to get help.

Not only do you need people, but those same people need you.

You have strengths, gifts, talents, and a personality that’s unique to you and beneficial to them—and vice versa. Why bury them in the ground, in the name of autonomy, when they can benefit others?

Sometimes we need to ask for help, and sometimes we need to be the help. Do you need help, or can you offer it? Could you use a hand, or do you have some time, money, advice, or expertise? 

If you’re tempted to self-isolate, don’t forget: we were meant to live life together.

YouVersion Daily Devotional

One of the things that gives me the hick the most is seeing people who claim to be healers not share their gifts with the world when it needs them the most. 

This silence is worrisome yet sheds a light on who is really in for the healing and upgrade of Earth and who is simply not there yet.

I understand that most of us are empats and it might indeed be very hard to show up in moments of global distress. I get it. I am one too.

Said this, it is our duty to do the work in our self to then be able to hold who and what needs our assistance.

This also relates very much to people who don’t do this as a profession. Yes, you can help too.

Our energy is contagious: if our frequency is low we cannot possibly support the one of others who might need support. It really comes down to quantum physics.

So how do you raise your frequency so to support yourself and your community?

You mediate, you move your body, you do breath work, mantras and use all the somatic tools that can support you calm your nervous system down and literally move stuck energy in your body. 

(These are just examples and it will be up to you to try different tools to see what resonates more to you. The healing path is not the same for everyone, this is why I constantly stress the benefits of working 1:1 with a practitioner).

But you can bring it a step forward and you can teach your communities the same somatic techniques you used on yourself and tell them to pass them along…this has the power to heal maybe just one person, maybe “just” a community, maybe the whole world.

Regardless of your stand in this conflict, but especially if it is one that is divisive, I encourage you to work on your shadows through somatic work so to help you support yourself and your community.

Once you do the work, you will clearly see that what we are experiencing in the world, which do not limit themselves to what we are seeing in P@lestine and !srael, are merely political and being divisive only supports their aggravation. I beg you to look at the bigger picture.

If you can support financially the path to peace, consider donating at the link in my bio 🙏🏼

As we see the distressing images and painful news coming out of the conflict in Israel and Gaza, join us in praying for peace and mercy using this prayer provided by @evangelicalalliance Fred Drummond:

God rich in mercy and love,
We pray for the people of Israel and Gaza.
For the innocents, broken, scared, frightened, confused.
God who weeps with the weeping, have mercy.

We think of those who have lost their lives and those who grieve.
God who meets us in the darkness of the valley and in the stillness of the night,
Oh God, meet with the bereaved.

For families shattered and children torn,
Oh God, have mercy.
To the injured, bring healing.
To the bereaved, bring comfort.
To the frightened, bring love.
To the weary, bring hope.

God of grace, we pray for an end to bloodshed.
May peace come quickly.
We pray that peacemakers may find a voice and offer a way forward.
Father, have mercy.
Lord Christ, have mercy.
Holy Spirit, bring hope.
Amen

We work in hospitality, it’s our job to be people pleasers, right?

Wrong.

It’s our job to ensure customers have a fabulous experience, but it’s also our personal responsibility to ensure we set healthy boundaries.

If you find yourself doing the following, you might just be a people pleaser:
✔️ Wanting to be liked by everybody
✔️ Being Agreeable
✔️ Apologising frequently
✔️ Putting others’ needs before your own
✔️ Avoiding conflict
✔️ Not sharing your opinion

We have the ability to shift out of people pleasing, and it often starts with the way we communicate. Little changes here and there with our mindset, can make all the difference.

Do you have any phrase suggestions to add to our list?

Early in 2003, @leymahgbowee met with six other women in a makeshift office/conference room to discuss the Liberian civil war and the fast-approaching war on the capital Monrovia. Armed with nothing but their conviction and 10 United States dollars, the Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace campaign was born. ⁠
⁠
"We worked daily confronting warlords, meeting with dictators, and refusing to be silenced in the face of AK-47s and RPGs. We walked when we had no transportation, we fasted when water was unaffordable, we held hands in the face of danger, we spoke truth to power when everyone else was being diplomatic, we stood under the rain and the sun with our children to tell the world the stories of the other side of the conflict. Our educational backgrounds, travel experiences, faiths, and social classes did not matter. We had a common agenda: Peace for Liberia Now." ⁠
⁠
In 2011 Leymah Gbowee was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her work leading the campaign. In her acceptance speech, she reflected on leading the nonviolent women's movement that was pivotal in ending Liberia's 14-year civil war in 2003: "We succeeded when no one thought we would; we were the conscience of the ones who had lost their consciences in their quest for power and political positions. We represented the soul of the nation. No one would have prepared my sisters and me for today — that our struggle would go down in the history of this world. Rather, when confronting warlords, we did so because we felt it was our moral duty to stand as mothers and gird our waist, to fight the demons of war in order to protect the lives of our children, their land, and their future."⁠
⁠
In her speech and through her actions, Gbowee reminds us of the role that individuals can play in achieving peace.⁠
⁠
Go to the link in bio to read the full speech and to learn more.⁠
⁠
--⁠
Pictured:⁠
First: In 2011, Leymah Gbowee and fellow women’s rights activists gathered on a soccer field where they had once prayed for peace during the civil war in Liberia.⁠
⁠
Second: August 28, 2003, Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace protestors at a march in front of the ECOMIL headquarters in Monrovia.

According to the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), since violence erupted between Israel and Hamas on October 7th, at least 22 journalists have been killed.

The CPJ reported that, as of October 20, 18 Palestinian, three Israeli, and one Lebanese journalist had died since Hamas militants attacked Israel on October 7, followed by the ongoing bombardments of Gaza by Israel.

The 22 journalists were among the more than 4,000 dead on both sides since the war began on October 7, with hundreds killed in Tuesday’s hospital blast in Gaza.

The CPJ attributed two of these fatalities to Hamas attacks in southern Israel and 15 of these deaths to Israeli airstrikes. According to reports, eight journalists have been hurt, and three more are either missing or in custody.

“CPJ emphasizes that journalists are civilians doing important work during times of crisis and must not be targeted by warring parties,” said Sherif Mansour, CPJ’s Middle East and North Africa program coordinator. “Journalists across the region are making great sacrifices to cover this heartbreaking conflict. All parties must take steps to ensure their safety.”

The CPJ said that it was probing "numerous unconfirmed reports of other journalists being killed, missing, detained, hurt or threatened, and of damage to media offices and journalists’ homes".

Follow the #VirtualBookTour for In Truth, Madness by Imran Khan @imranism  @breakthrough_book_collective 

The perfect read for Neil Gaiman fans. 

Meet Malek Khalil, a brilliant reporter with decades of experience in the field, and a man on the edge. Where there is war, natural disaster or political crisis, Malek is in the midst of it, but years of conflict reporting have taken their toll and he is slowly unravelling. 
His colleagues, Neeka and Justin, have noticed a change in him, beyond even his usual vivid imagination. Neeka is especially sensitive, having been his friend and producer for many years, and perhaps knowing him better than he knows himself. Justin, a skilled and brave cameraman, has worked with them for just as long and the three make a formidable team - but they are only as strong as each other - and Malek is fast going down the rabbit hole.

Born a Muslim but an atheist to his core, Malek's voyage takes him around the world and back in time to ancient Babylon, as he finds himself arguing with a God in whom he does not believe. A keen reader, his 'madness' is heightened by a strange book that keeps appearing on his Kindle, telling the stories of people he has briefly encountered during his career.

In Truth, Madness takes place in the Middle East, South Asia and London against a backdrop of war, religion, political skullduggery and emerging love, taking the reader on a tumultuous journey through the most dangerous arenas of modern culture and the ancient world. 

Is Malek losing his mind, or is he experiencing an astonishing kind of truth? 

Our hosts on Monday will be @afelton6212  and @littlethaosbookshelf

As it was about losing body fat or gaining lean muscle.

When Ashley started her journey with us, she was already very active being a triathlete.

Cycled 3x a week...

An animal rescue in Lebanon is also caught up in what is happening in Gaza.  If you can, please donate to help them help the animals of Lebanon • @animalslebanon This is a very difficult time – we can help each other

The situation is tense in the region. Our thoughts are with the people suffering and most affected. 

We are sad, we are stressed, we are scared - mostly we feel helpless. Each hour that goes by brings a possibility of conflict spilling over.

We have to be strong – not for us but for the animals that depend on us. We have over 100 cats and dogs, two young lions, six baboons, and other wildlife we are working on. Lions scheduled to leave to a sanctuary in South Africa, baboons to a sanctuary in the UK, cats and dogs to various countries. These trips are now at risk and we fear they might be stuck.

We are now receiving dozens of requests per day for help with people leaving Lebanon with their pets. We are helping make sure they have the right documents and permits, buy traveling cages, making flight reservations, or updating veterinary records so they are prepared in case they need to leave suddenly. 

We are trying to build up a three-to-six-month supply for our own animals and so we can help the community.

We have to be prepared in case the situation gets worse.

We've been pretty quiet about what's happening in the world, trying to keep this a place of positivity and light. At the same time, we can't ignore the devastation that is occurring in Israel and Palestine. I'll be frank and say that, while I am no pacificist, the reaction of violence to meet violence is abhorrent, and the full breadth of a greater force's power to meet the attack of a smaller force is extreme, unnecessary, and against God.

As LGBTQIA2S+ people, we know what it is like to be considered less than human. We know what it is like to experience the violence of others for their own sport. We know what it is like to have others tell us to just be calm, to not be angry, and to work for peace in a conflict we did not start. Even more, we know what it is like to have "spokespeople" misconstrue our wishes, our voices, and our very selves in their efforts to gain recognition. This conflict, at its core, is not strange to us. 

And so, we pray for peace. Not cheap peace. Not the sort of peace that comes at the expense of marginalized people and to the benefit of those already filled with power. Not a peace that pleases the leaders of nations but leaves their people captive to the desires of a very slim few. We pray for true peace, the kind of peace that comes with justice, the kind of peace that is hard work to achieve, the kind that requires sacrifice and vulnerability, and the kind that leads to true and deep reconciliation. We pray for the kind of peace that comes with the quiet flaps of the wings of the Spirit, landing with God's gentleness among the cacophony of war, bringing all to a standstill. And, as we discuss this issue from positions of great privilege and safety, God, make us gentle - slow to judge, and quick to care.

Making art has always been a way for me to make sense of my emotions and to better understand others. I am grateful that I have the opportunities to continue doing so, and to simply exist without fear for my life.
-
I said this in a story, but I think it’s important to repeat: Though I won’t pretend to understand the deep history and nuance of this conflict, I do know that war crimes & the desecration of life are always grave tragedies.
-
I believe that all people are made in the image of God (Genesis 1:26), meaning that each person is a reflection of the Father, Son, & Spirit, and have inherent dignity, beauty, and worth. 
Yet, we see examples of the ways in which humankind has fallen far, constantly displaying our brokenness against each other; horrendous events like these are a crushing reminder of that.
-
I do not intend to make political statements, just to express my grief over the senseless violence against innocent victims on both sides being faced with the aftermath of decisions that were and are completely out of their control. Condemning evil can be done without dehumanizing entire people groups.
-
Jesus of Nazareth was and is the Prince of Peace and the God of Justice, and what I cling to in dark days (even with fingers that feel like they are slipping at times) is that He is the “man of sorrows and acquainted with grief” —Isaiah 53:3. He weeps with us even while there is eternal hope (Lazarus in John 11); His return means that wickedness and death itself will be buried in the end.

- Vibha Galhotra writes about life in Jerusalem.

21 octobre 1988 (35 ans aujourd'hui) ...Small Parts Isolated and Destroyed...troisième album complet du groupe punk rock vancouvérois NoMeansNo...deuxième album des frères Rob et John Wright avec le guitariste de longue date Andy Kerr et le premier enregistré après avoir signé avec l'éminent label punk rock Alternative Tentacles (label indépendant fondé par les Dead Kennedys en 1979)...probablement L'album le plus expérimental tant au niveau du son que de la composition, et se classe parmi les albums les plus difficiles de NoMeansNo...qui s'inspire à la fois du punk et du jazz
...enregistré en 1987 en même temps que le EP sorti en 1988 lui aussi "The Day Everything Became Nothing"..qui seront plus tard réunis sur un cd sous le nom de The Day Everything Became Isolated and Destroyed!

À l'automne 1988... ma transition vers le punk/hardcore était commencé depuis l'été...mon chum Dom qui a un cousin plus vieux de 3 ou 4 ans de plus que nous (nous avions 14 ans en 88) agissait comme un mentor pour notre éducation musicale punk/hardcore (surtout pour les groupes obscurs et underground à l'époque)...il nous a fait découvrir :Subhumans, Crass, Conflict, Butthole Surfers, 7 Seconds, Alice Donut ect.. et surtout NoMeansNo qui était une révélation pour moi...il n'y a pas un band qui sonne comme NoMeansNo...original et unique...classé comme du punk pour la philosophie mais musicalement c'est plus prog/jazz meet punk/hardcore..Nomeansno a eu une grosse influence sur la naissance du "math rock"...je portais un gilet de Small Parts Isolated and Destroyed en 1989 et c'était le premier album de NoMeansNo que j'ai connu (mon album préféré du groupe c'est Wrong sorti l'année suivante en 1989) ...je me rappelle quand Nothingface de Voïvod est sorti je trouvais que la bass et les structures des chansons avec une petite influence de NoMeansNo...NoMeansNo band de chefs!

#NoMeansNo

HM King meets Jordanian Monarch

Cairo, Oct. 21 (BNA): His Majesty King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa met here today His Majesty King Abdullah II ibn Al-Hussein of Jordan, on the sidelines of their participation in the Cairo Peace Summit, hosted by Egypt to discuss the latest developments and future of the Palestinian cause. 
 
HM King Hamad and HM King Abdullah II stressed the need to intensify and unify Arab efforts to deescalate the situation in the Gaza Strip, while giving priority to cooperating with the International Community to stop the conflict immediately, allow the entry of humanitarian aid into Gaza, lift the siege and protect civilians.
 
The two leaders warned that the continuity of the ongoing escalation could lead to dangerous repercussions and a new spiral of violence.

Anastasia Samoylovas first solo exhibition in France opened at PHAKT - Cultural Center in Rennes today.

From 13 October to 22 December & you can visit the artist’s show "FloodZone".

—

FloodZone, the first solo exhibition in France by American artist Anastasia Samoylova, is a photographic narrative exploring the problem of rising sea levels in an area south of Florida.

FloodZone was initiated when the artist moved to Miami in 2016. Through daily walks, Anastasia Samoylova began to reflect on the growing conflict between the booming tourist and property market and the regular intrusion of the ocean on its coastline, as in 2017 when the city was particularly devastated by Hurricane Irma.

While the economic forces at work contribute to a feeling of denial and disavowal, Anastasia Samoylova's photographs convey what it feels like to live in a paradise teetering on the brink of disaster.

As part of the @glaz.festival photography festival
With the support of the Guernsey Photography Festival and Guernsey Museum

Special thanks to @jchristophe_godet
@phakt_centreculturelcolombier @glaz.festival

Middle East Airlines Moves Most of its Planes from Lebanon

Lebanese carrier Middle East Airlines (MEA) decided to move a number of its airplanes to neighboring countries as a precaution in case of conflict, thus reducing the number of its daily flights from and to Beirut.

The decision came after changes to the company’s insurance coverage policy following the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.

MEA said it was informed by the insurance companies about a decision to reduce their war risk coverage.

Mohammed Al-Hout, chairman of MEA, said only eight of the company’s 22 planes would operate as of next week, with the rest relocated to other airports.

Only one-third of the company’s flights scheduled before the crisis will remain operational.

Two-state solution supported by HM King only guarantor for regional stability: Speaker

Manama, Oct. 21 (BNA): Ahmed bin Salman Al Musallam, Speaker of the Council of Representatives, has affirmed that the supportive stance of the Kingdom of Bahrain, under the leadership of His Majesty King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa, and the support of His Royal Highness Prince Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa, the Crown Prince and Prime Minister, towards the Palestinians is unequivocal.

He indicated that Bahrain firmly supports the Palestinian people’s legitimate rights to establish their independent state, and believes that there would be no stability in the Middle East without securing those rights to the Palestinians.

He pointed out that HM King Hamad always affirmed that the two-state solution is the only guarantor for promoting coexistence and ending the conflict, and that diplomacy is the only way to settle all disputes, adding that the kingdom backs all Arab, regional and international efforts to contain the dangerous crisis and halt the ongoing military operations across the Palestinian territories.

Speaker Al Musallam underlined parliamentary support for HM the King’s call for providing protection for innocent civilians from both sides, releasing all detainees and hostages, facilitating entry of humanitarian aid into the Gaza Strip, as per the International Humanitarian Law, and categorical rejection of the displacement of Gazans from their lands. He said this was the only feasible track to spare the region a humanitarian catastrophe of endless repercussions.

Posted @withregram • @middleeasteye London’s Metropolitan Police on Friday said they will not be arresting anyone chanting a popular slogan used by Palestinian activists during demonstrations.

The slogan in question, “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”, is commonly heard at solidarity marches and refers to the area of historic Palestine between the River Tiberias and the Mediterranean Sea.

Pro-Israel groups claim it is antisemitic because it is an implicit call for the destruction of Israel, a charge rejected by Palestinian activists.

The police force’s guidance comes ahead of what are expected to be large demonstrations in support of Palestinians on Saturday.

Passions have been running high in the UK as the conflict in Gaza rages on. Palestinian activists have previously expressed concerns about the criminalisation of political expression and free speech when it comes to criticising Israel.

Earlier in October, British Home Secretary Suella Braverman advised police forces across the country to look into the possibility of whether the waving of Palestinian flags amounted to a criminal offence.

“Behaviours that are legitimate in some circumstances, for example, the waving of a Palestinian flag, may not be legitimate such as when intended to glorify acts of terrorism,” she wrote in a letter to police chiefs.

As things stand, under British law, expressions of support for proscribed groups, such as Hamas or Hezbollah, can lead to arrest with the possibility of fines and prison sentences for those convicted of an offence.

The civil rights group Liberty has condemned what it calls the government’s attack on “the ability to stand up for what we believe in is our fundamental right”.

“Recent government responses to protests relating to Israel and Palestine are an attack on that right, and an attempt to erode the way we can make our voices heard,” the group said in a statement on X, formerly known as Twitter.

English footballing legend Sir Bobby Charlton has sadly passed away, aged 86. Our thoughts are with Sir Bobby’s family, friends and everyone connected with Manchester United at this time. Words cannot do justice to the impact Sir Bobby Charlton had on the trajectory of both Manchester United and the English game as a whole, but we feel it’s only right to pay homage to one of the greatest ever. World Cup winner. Ballon d’Or winner. European Cup winner. The long-time record goalscorer for both Manchester United and England. Just 20-years-old when he survived the tragic Munich air disaster, drawing strength from those around him and championing an era which acted as a catalyst for Manchester United’s future success. And, whilst his legacy was crafted on the pitch, it was only further cemented by his achievements outside the game. Founded the ‘Find a Better Way’ charity in 2011, having seen first-hand the humanitarian damage caused by landmines on visits to Cambodia and Bosnia-Herzegovina. Created the Sir Bobby Charlton Foundation, also, to help those whose lives have been affected by conflict and war. Awarded an OBE in 1969 and CBE in 1974, before receiving his knighthood in 1994. The English game was gifted a figure much bigger than football and a legend in every sense of the word. May his legacy last on.

 H.H. Sheikha Latifa bint Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Chairperson of the Dubai Culture and Arts Authority and Member of the Dubai Council, today visited the ‘Tarahum for Gaza’ campaign centre in Dubai where she met with volunteers and participated in packing relief packages.
A total of 2,600 volunteers helped prepare more than 7,500 relief packages for the relief campaign. These packages were intended to provide support and demonstrate solidarity with Palestinians who have been affected by the ongoing conflict in Gaza.
Organised at Qalaat Alremaal Events in Dubai, the community event, overseen by Dubai Cares, part of the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Global Initiatives, saw volunteers, including citizens and residents of all ages and nationalities volunteer their time to prepare food and relief kits for babies and women. Her Excellency Hessa bint Essa Buhumaid, Director General of Dubai’s Community Development Authority also accompanied HH Sheikha Latifa bint Mohammed during the visit.
The 'Tarahum for Gaza' campaign, initiated just last week aims to express solidarity with Palestinians suffering from the current conflict and alleviate the harsh humanitarian conditions and suffering faced by the most vulnerable groups. Among these vulnerable groups, children represent a significant portion, with over 1 million children constituting more than half of the Gaza Strip’s population.
The campaign is supervised by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in cooperation with the Emirates Red Crescent Authority and the World Food Programme, and in coordination with the Ministry of Community Development. The initiative is supported by 20 relief and humanitarian organisations.
The campaign continues tomorrow with two events taking place at the Abu Dhabi National Exhibition Centre (ADNEC) under the supervision of the UAE Red Crescent; and the Sharjah Expo Centre under the supervision of Sharjah Charity

October 20, 2023

Israel has been isolating the Palestinian struggle from its regional context, writes Ramzy Baroud. Palestine must, once more, become an issue that concerns all Arabs.

By Ramzy Baroud
MintPress News

At one time, the “Arab-Israeli Conflict” was Arab and Israeli. Over many years, however, it was rebranded. The media is now telling us it is a “Hamas-Israeli conflict.”

But what went wrong? Israel simply became too powerful.

The supposedly astounding Israeli victories over the years against Arab armies have emboldened Israel to the extent that it came to view itself not as a regional superpower but as a global power. Israel, per its own definition, became invincible.”

Such terminology was not a mere scare tactic aimed at breaking the spirit of Palestinians and Arabs alike. Israel believed this.

The “Israeli miracle victory” against Arab armies in 1967 was a watershed moment. Then, Israel’s Foreign Minister Abba Eban, declared in a speech at the United Nations that “from the podium of the U.N., I proclaimed the glorious triumph of the IDF and the redemption of Jerusalem.”

In his thinking, this could only mean one thing: “Never before has Israel stood more honored and revered by the nations of the world.”

The sentiment in Eban’s words echoed throughout Israel. Even those who doubted their government’s ability to prevail over the Arabs completely joined the chorus: Israel is unvanquishable.

Little rational discussion took place back then about the actual reasons why Israel had won and if that victory would have been possible without Washington’s complete backing and the West’s willingness to support Israel at any cost.

15 Palestinians, in new Israeli airstrikes in Gaza.

At least 15 Palestinians, including four children, were killed in renewed Israeli airstrikes on the Gaza Strip, the Gaza Interior Ministry said Saturday.

A statement said 10 were killed when Israeli fighter jets struck two houses in Deir al-Balah in central Gaza.

And four children and a woman were killed in a separate strike on a house east of Rafah in southern Gaza, it said

The conflict in Gaza, under Israeli bombardment and blockade since Oct. 7, began when Hamas initiated Operation Al-Aqsa Flood -- a multi-pronged surprise attack that included a barrage of rocket launches and infiltrations into Israel by land, sea and air.

Hamas said the incursion was in retaliation for the storming of the Al-Aqsa Mosque and growing violence by Israeli settlers.

The Israeli military then launched Operation Swords of Iron against Hamas targets in the Gaza Strip, putting the territory's 2.3 million residents under total siege and a blockade of food, fuel and medical supplies

UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres urged an "immediate humanitarian cease-fire" to ease the "epic human suffering."

At least 4,137 Palestinians, including 1,524 children and 1,000 women have been killed in Israeli attacks on Gaza. That figure stands at more than 1,400 in Israel

Discover Maki Gallery at ASIA NOW 2023. 

@maki_gallery_tokyo specializes in the realm of post-war and contemporary Japanese art. Moreover, the gallery is deeply devoted to fostering and championing emerging talents, embracing a diverse spectrum of artists, both from Japan and abroad. 

Keisuke Tada employs acrylic paint and trompe l’oeil techniques to create hyperrealistic assemblages of wood, tiles, and chains as well as imagined Old Master paintings, each complete with signs of wear and tear. The paintings are inspired by the @vilkeisuke wanderings of the virtual plane and subvert ideas of authenticity by blurring the boundary between reality and fiction. 

Born in 1986 in Aichi, Japan, Keisuke Tada received both his BFA and MFA in oil painting from Aichi University of the Arts in 2010 and 2012, respectively. Fascinated by the sensory experiences offered by video games and other virtual worlds, Tada creates paintings that explore the blurry boundary separating reality and fiction. His trace / dimension series mimics assemblages of wooden boards, metal chains, and ceramic tiles; his Heaven’s Door series resembles antique doors that seem to have been attacked with an axe. Despite their convincing appearances, the works are crafted entirely out of paint. In Paintings of incomplete remains, the artist fabricates time by artificially aging the surface of each canvas, yielding them a likeness to classical European paintings. It could be said that Tada, who investigates the conflict between what exists and what doesn’t through his unconventional techniques, brings new dimension to the medium of painting.

📸: Keisuke Tada, trace / dimension #63, 2023

This months pick from our bookshop is "On Freedom: Four Songs of Care and Constraint" by Maggie Nelson.

"An expansive, exhilarating work of non-fiction on freedom, by the bestselling, internationally acclaimed writer. 

Drawing on a vast range of material, from critical theory to pop culture to the intimacies and plain exchanges of daily life, Maggie Nelson explores how we might think, experience, or talk about freedom in ways responsive to the conditions of our day. Her abiding interest lies in ongoing “practices of freedom” by which we negotiate our interrelation with―indeed, our inseparability from―others, with all the care and constraint that entails, while accepting difference and conflict as integral to our communion."

First published by Jonathan Cape in 2021
Penguin Random House, UK

Over the next two days, I’ll be talking about (1) how to make your partner feel safe in a relationship and (2) how to create your own safety in a relationship.
⠀⠀
You can make your partner feel safe in a relationship by putting the following tips into practice:
⠀⠀
1. Have Empathy
• Empathy is the ability to connect with your partner’s thoughts and feelings.
• The most powerful form is empathy is listening and validating.
• After a long day, ask your partner, “Is there anything you need to talk about? I’m here to listen.”
• Practice saying “I’m sorry” and ‘I apologize for hurting you” after a mistake.
⠀⠀
2. Always Give Reassurance
• Reassurance is the ability to remove your partner’s doubts about the relationship.
• No matter how secure your partner appears, he or she will have moments when they doubt your love. Therefore, reassurance is necessary.
• Ask your partner often, “How can I give you reassurance? I don’t want you to question my loyalty.”
⠀⠀
3. Practice Healthy Conflict Management
• Poor conflict management is the leading cause of feeling unsafe in a relationship.
•Does your partner feel like you’re going to leave because of a disagreement? This is not okay.
• Does your partner feel more distant than close to you after a conflict? This is not okay.
• If you want to learn healthy conflict management, schedule an appointment to work with me.
⠀⠀
4. Be Trustworthy
• Safety and trust work together.
• Trust creates safety.
• There are five trustworthy behaviors: (1) honest communication, (2) honoring boundaries, (3) reliability, (4) predicability and (5) loyalty.
⠀⠀
5. Spend Quality Time Together
• Presence is the most powerful thing in a relationship.
• Spending quality time with your partner, without being distracted, is the best way to create safety.
⠀⠀
Each of these tips will help your partner feel safe with you. I’ll talk about how to create your own safety in a relationship tomorrow. If you have any other tips, please share them in the comments below ❤️

Making The Marriage Work
Preacher: Pastor Femi Awodele

Matthew 19:1, 1 Thessalonians 5:23, 

Two major parts of our essence are:

•Nature: what we pick from genes, hereditary traits...
•Nurture: what you learn via grooming.

Psychologically we can be placed in three traits:

•Aggressive personality trait: they explode when angry

•Passive/aggressive personality: they are not so expressive or spontaneous expression.

•Passive personality: they are  typically laid back in their expression.

Our personalities and cultures impact our marital choice.For a marriage to work, one has to align with Biblical principles.

Communication is key in resolving conflicts. Talking is different from communication. Talking could be one way, but communication is a two-way process.

Keynotes in communication:
• What you say
•Tone
•Body language.

Relevant communication skills:
•Attend
•Acknowledge
•Invite
•Summarize
•Ask; ask questions for clarification.
•Share your feelings.
•Disclose what you want, and make suggestions.

Note: use the word "I" more than "you".

How to communicate:
•Set a time!
•Do not demean your spouse by spewing negativity.
•Don't be historical! 
•Avoid defensive words like NEVER and ALWAYS
•Do not bring children into your fights!
•Always start by saying something endearing about your spouse. Psychologically, when you approach someone with endearing words, it alleviates their tension.

Steps to conflict resolution:
•Set a time!
•Separate the person from the issue. Understand the why.
•Seek Godly strategy.

Note: God created your wife to complement you.

How to maintain your marriage: 1 Thessalonians 5:23, Acts 2:42;

•Word
•Study
•Prayer
•Fellowship
•Take care of yourself! 
•Sex: it has a spiritual connotation.

The mind is what makes you make a decision, while the will is what makes you implement it or not.

Note: make up your mind on biblical principles, and submit yourself to God's will.

Madeleine Mantock graces Square Mile’s Digital Spotlight cover to discuss all things Hamnet, and her experience taking the lead as Agnes Hathaway in the West End show.

Per Square Mile: ‘A story told over a period of 20 years, the show has all the staples of a play written by the bard himself. There’s mystery and magic, a forbidden love story, and a tragedy all too heavy to bear. But don’t let the title fool you. Hamnet is its name, and Shakespeare walks the stage, but the spotlight falls on his wife, Agnes Hathaway. 

The woman at the edge of the forest, Agnes has the ability to look at a person and see right through to their soul. She is played by Madeleine Mantock, a woman not unfamiliar with magical roles.’
